z.explanation: The 26th letter of the modern English alphabet.
Any of the speech sounds represented by the letter z.
The 26th in a series.
Something shaped like the letter Z.
Sleep.
In astronomy , an abbreviation of Zonæ Cordobenses , Gould's Cordova Zones. See C. Z .
An abbreviation of Zoölogical Garden or Gardens.
mathematics :
lowercase ] In algebra, the third variable or unknown quantity.
lowercase ] In analytical geometry, one of the system of point-coördinates in space.

The twenty-sixth letter of the basic modern Latin alphabet .

voiced alveolar fricative
The twenty-sixth letter of the English alphabet , called zed or zee and written in the Latin script .
the ending of a series or sequence
the 26th letter of the Roman alphabet

za.explanation: An intensive or augmentative prefix sometimes used in forming modern scientific words to emphasize the character or quality noted by the element to which it is prefixed (like E. very , a.), as in zalambdodont , having teeth with a very V-shaped ridge, Zalophus, Zamelodia, Zapus , etc.
In solmization , a syllable once used for Bь.

An old solfeggio name for B flat; the seventh harmonic, as heard in the or æolian string; -- so called by Tartini. It was long considered a false, but is the true note of the chord of the flat seventh.
A syllable formerly used in solfège to represent B flat.

zabaglione.explanation: A dessert or sauce consisting of egg yolks, sugar, and wine or liqueur beaten until thick and served hot or cold.
A custard-like dessert made with egg yolks , sugar and Marsala wine
light foamy custard-like dessert served hot or chilled

zabra.explanation: A small vessel used on the coasts of Spain.
A small sailing vessel used off the coasts of Spain and Portugal .

zac.explanation: A sixpence ; (sometimes after decimalisation ) a 5-cent coin.

zacate.explanation: In Mexico, the southwestern United States, Guam, and the Philippines, a name applied to grasses, especially to those used for hay or fresh forage. Under this name the rice-grass, Homalocenchrus hexandrus , a grass of Mexican origin, is cultivated in the Philippines for fodder. See rice-grass .

zacaton.explanation: In the southwestern United States and Mexico: One of several grasses useful for hay, especially Epicampes macroura and species of Sporobolus ; specifically, Sporobolus Wrightii , which in Arizona and New Mexico yields a hay valued in lieu of better for horses and mules. It grows in great clumps, producing a largo amount of coarse, tough stems and leaves.

zachun.explanation: An oil pressed by the Arabs from the fruit of a small thorny tree ( Balanites Ægyptiaca ), and sold to piligrims for a healing ointment.
An oil pressed by the Arabs from the fruit of a small thorny tree (Balanites aegyptiaca), and sold to pilgrims for a healing ointment .

zack.explanation: A six-month or six-year prison sentence .

zadokite.explanation: One of the sons of Zadok, who, according to Ezekiel, were the only legitimate priests.

zadruga.explanation: Among the South Slavic peoples, the association of all consanguineals into a coöperative organization, the members of which generally live in a complex of houses built within an inclosure and around the house of the stare-shina or chief of the community.
A social unit of rural community among the South Slavs, associated with family links and set customs.

zaffer.explanation: An impure oxide of cobalt, used to produce a blue color in enamel and in the making of smalt.
The residuum of cobalt-producing ores after the sulphur, arsenic, and other volatile matters have been more or less completely expelled by roasting.

A pigment obtained, usually by roasting cobalt glance with sand or quartz, as a dark earthy powder. It consists of crude cobalt oxide, or of an impure cobalt arseniate. It is used in porcelain painting, and in enameling pottery, to produce a blue color, and is often confounded with smalt, from which, however, it is distinct, as it contains no potash. The name is often loosely applied to mixtures of zaffer proper with silica, or oxides of iron, manganese, etc.

A pigment obtained, usually by roasting cobalt glance with sand or quartz , as a dark earthy powder . It consists of crude cobalt oxide, or of an impure cobalt arseniate. It is used in porcelain painting , and in enameling pottery , to produce a blue color, and is often confounded with smalt , from which, however, it is distinct, as it contains no potash . The name is often loosely applied to mixtures of zaffer proper with silica , or oxides of iron , manganese , etc.

zaffre.explanation: a blue pigment obtained by roasting cobalt ore
a cobalt blue colour, like that of the pigment

zaftig.explanation: Having a full, shapely figure. Used of a woman.
Of a woman, having a plump and sexually attractive figure; voluptuous , well-proportioned.
(of a female body) healthily plump and vigorous

zag.explanation: One of a series of sharp turns or reversals.
To turn or change direction suddenly. Usually used in contrast to zig .
To behave erratically or indecisively. Usually used with zig .
One of a series of sharp turns or reversals .
to move with a sharp turn or reversal
an angular shape characterized by sharp turns in alternating directions

zagged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zag .

zaglossus.explanation: The proper name of that genus of prickly ant-eaters which is better known by its synonym Acanthoglossus (which see).

zaguan.explanation: A porch or a vestibule at the entrance of a house; entrance; hall.

zaibatsu.explanation: A Japanese conglomerate, especially a powerful family-controlled monopoly before World War II.
Japanese term for ‘money clique ’ or conglomerate , and sometimes used in the United States to refer to any large corporation .

zain.explanation: A horse of a dark color, neither gray nor white, and having no spots.
A horse of a dark colour with no lighter spots .

zaire.explanation: The unit of currency of Zaire .

zaitha.explanation: A genus of waterbugs, of the family Belostomatidæ , peculiar to America.

zak.explanation: Sixpence or a "small amount of money".

zakat.explanation: The obligatory contribution of a certain portion of one's wealth in support of the poor or needy or for other charitable purposes, considered as one of the duties of Islamic religious practice.
The amount owed or contributed for these purposes.
almsgiving , one of the five pillars of Islam
the fourth pillar of Islam is almsgiving as an act of worship

zalambdodont.explanation: Zalambdodonta : as, a zalambdodont dentition; a zalambdodont mammal: opposed to dilambdodont.
One of the Zalambdodonta . The tenrec, solenodon, and golden moles are examples.
Of or pertaining to a tribe ( Zalambdodonta ) of Insectivora in which the molar teeth have but one V-shaped ridge.
Having teeth with two ridges that meet at an angle , forming the letter lambda .
A creature with teeth of this kind.

zalambdodonta.explanation: A group or series of insectivorous mammals; a division of the suborder Bestiæ , or Insectivora vera , having short molars whose crowns present one V-shaped transverse ridge, a formation characteristic of the insectivores of tropical regions, which are thus contrasted with temperate and northerly forms ( Dilambdodonta ).

zalophus.explanation: A genus of otaries, or eared seals: so named from the high parietal crest or ridge of the skull.

zaman.explanation: Albizia saman , a large tropical tree in the pea family
large ornamental tropical American tree with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and seed pods that are eaten by cattle

zamang.explanation: An immense leguminous tree ( Pithecolobium Saman ) of Venezuela. Its branches form a hemispherical mass, often one hundred and eighty feet across. The sweet pulpy pods are used commonly for feeding cattle. Also called rain tree .
large ornamental tropical American tree with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and seed pods that are eaten by cattle

zamarra.explanation: A sheepskin coat worn in parts of Spain

zambo.explanation: The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of an Indian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.

zambomba.explanation: A rude Spanish musical instrument, consisting of an earthen jar the top of which is covered with parchment, through which a stick is inserted.
A Spanish percussion instrument , a drum played by pulling a rope .

zamboorak.explanation: A light swivelling gun , traditionally mounted on, and fired from, the the back of a camel

zamia.explanation: Any of various chiefly tropical American cycads of the genus Zamia, having a thick, usually underground stem, palmlike terminal leaves, and seeds borne in woody cones.
A genus of gymnospermous plants, of the order Cycadaceæ , type of the tribe Zamieæ.
[ l. c ] A plant of this genus.
A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood. See coontie , and Illust. of strobile .
Any of various cycads of the genus Zamia
any of various cycads of the genus Zamia; among the smallest and most verdant cycads

zamiaceae.explanation: a family of cycads often included in the family Cycadaceae: zamias

zamindar.explanation: An official in precolonial India assigned to collect the land taxes of his district.
A landholder in British colonial India responsible for collecting and paying to the government the taxes on the land under his jurisdiction.
A landowner; also, a collector of land revenue; now, usually, a kind of feudatory recognized as an actual proprietor so long as he pays to the government a certain fixed revenue.
a landowner , especially on the Indian subcontinent, one paying tax directly to the British government

zamindari.explanation: The system of tax collection by zamindars.
The area administered by a zamindar.

In British India , a system used to collect revenues from the ryots (cultivators of agricultural land) indirectly through the zamindars , as opposed to ryotwari , where revenues were collected directly.

zamindary.explanation: The jurisdiction of a zamindar; the land possessed by a zamindar.

zamouse.explanation: A West African buffalo, or bush-ox, found in Sierra Leone, Bos brachyceros , the short-horned buffalo, having the ears fringed with hair, short horns depressed at base, and no dewlap.

A West African buffalo ( Bubalus brachyceros ) having short horns depressed at the base, and large ears fringed internally with three rows of long hairs. It is destitute of a dewlap. Called also short-horned buffalo , and bush cow .
A West African buffalo with short horns and large ears .

zampogna.explanation: A sort of bagpipe formerly in use among Italian peasants. It is now almost obsolete.
A kind of Italian double- chantered bagpipe .

zanclodon.explanation: A genus of dinosaurs, typical of the family Zanclodontidæ , having both fore and hind feet five-toed, no ascending astragalar process, broad and long pubes, and biconcave vertebræ.

zander.explanation: A food and game fish (Sander lucioperca) of Europe and western Asia, found in fresh and brackish water.
The European pike-perch, Stizostedion lucioperca (formerly Lucioperca Sandra ). It inhabits fresh waters of central Europe. Also sander and zant.
A European pike perch ( Stizostedion lucioperca ) allied to the wall-eye; -- called also sandari , sander , sannat , schill , and zant .
A European freshwater fish in the family Percidae , closely related to perch , Sander lucioperca .
Any fish of the genus Sander that live in freshwater.

zandmole.explanation: Same as sand-mole . See cuts under Bathyergus and Georychus.
The sand mole or coast rat (Bathyergus suillus)

zanella.explanation: A twilled fabric used for covering umbrellas.
An Italian wool or twill fabric

zanier.explanation: comparative form of zany : more zany

zaniest.explanation: superlative form of zany : most zany .

zaniness.explanation: The state or condition of being zany .

zanjero.explanation: A man who patrols irrigation ditches to keep them in order or repair. See ditch-rider . Also zangero .

zannichellia.explanation: A genus of plants, of the order Naiadaceæ , type of the tribe Zannichellieæ.
horned pondweed: completely submerged herbs; in some classifications included in Potamogetonaceae

zannichelliaceae.explanation: alternative classification for some genera included in Potamogetonaceae; one species

zanonia.explanation: A genus of plants, of the order Cucurbitaceæ , type of the tribe Zanonieæ.

zantedeschia.explanation: A plant genus now known by the earlier name Richardia (which see).

zantewood.explanation: A yellow dyewood; fustet; -- called also zante , and zante fustic . See fustet , and the Note under fustic .

zanthoxylum.explanation: Any of the genus Zanthoxylum of deciduous and evergreen trees and shrubs in the citrus or rue family .
deciduous or evergreen trees or shrubs: prickly ash

zantiot.explanation: A native or inhabitant of Zante, one of the Ionian Islands.

zantiote.explanation: A native of Zante (ancient Zacynthus ), one of the Ionian Islands.

zany.explanation: Comical or ludicrous because of incongruity or strangeness.
A comical person given to extravagant or outlandish behavior.
A ludicrous, buffoonish character in old comedies who attempts feebly to mimic the tricks of the clown.

A comic performer, originating on the Italian stage, whose function it is to make awkward attempts at mimicking the tricks of the professional clown, or the acts of other performers; hence, an apish buffoon in general; a merry-andrew; an amusing fool.

Synonyms Clown, Fool, Buffoon, Mimic, Zany. “The zany in Shakespere's day was not so much a buffoon and mimic as the obsequious follower of a buffoon and the attenuated mime of a mimic. He was the vice, servant, or attendant of the professional clown or fool , who, dressed like his master, accompanied him on the stage or in the ring, following his movements, imitating his tricks. and adding to the general merriment by his ludicrous failures and comic imbecility … The professional clown or fool might be clever and accomplished in his business, a skilful tumbler and mountebank, doing what he undertook to do thoroughly and well. But this was never the case with the zany. He was always slight and thin, well-meaning, but comparatively helpless, full of readiness, grimace, and alacrity, but also of incompetence. eagerly trying to imitate his superior, but ending in failure and absurdity … We have ourselves seen the clown and the zany in the ring together, the clown doing clever tricks, the zany provoking immense laughter by his ludicrous failures in attempting to imitate them. Where there is only a single clown. he often combines both the characters, doing skilful tumbling on his own account, and playing the zany to the riders.” ( Edinburgh Rev. , July, 1869, art. 4.)
a man who is a stupid incompetent fool
a buffoon in one of the old comedies; imitates others for ludicrous effect

zanyism.explanation: The act or practice of imitation or mimicry.
The condition or habits of a buffoon or a low clown: often used contemptuously.
State or character of a zany; buffoonery.

zanzalian.explanation: A Jacobite of the East: so called occasionally from Zanzalus, a surname of Jacobus Baradæus. See Jacobite , 2.

zanze.explanation: An African musical instrument consisting of a wooden box in which a number of sonorous tongues of wood or metal are fixed. These are sounded by the finger or a stick.

zap.explanation: To strike (an object or target) with a beam of energy, an electric current, or supernatural power.
To expose to radiation, as to cook or examine.
In science fiction and fantasy, to transport (a person or thing) into another place or time instantaneously, as with an energy beam.
To destroy or kill.
To deplete or obliterate.
To have a sudden and powerful effect on.
To move swiftly; zoom.
To use a remote control to turn a television set on or off or to switch channels.
A burst or beam of energy, electric current, or other power.
A sudden and powerful effect.
Used to indicate a sudden occurrence.
to shoot, destroy, or inactivate.
to bomb with an atomic bomb.
to cook or heat in a microwave oven.
to subject to radiation, a laser beam, a strong electric current, or other potentially destructive treatment.
to skip over (e. g. a commercial or dull interval in a television program) by using the fast-forward button on a VCR remove control.
to add interest, color, or attractiveness to; to liven; -- usually used with up.
A sound made by a sudden release of electricity or some similar energy .
An electrical shock.
To make a zapping sound.
To use a remote control to repeatedly change channels on a television .
To strike (something or someone) with electricity or energy , as by shooting.
To damage (especially electronics) with electrostatic discharge .
To heat (something) in a microwave oven .
To delete or discard (electronic media).
To further energize or charge (magnetic material).
Representing the sound or action of a zap.
cook or heat in a microwave oven
a sudden event that imparts energy or excitement, usually with a dramatic impact
strike at with firepower or bombs
strike suddenly and with force
kill with or as if with a burst of gunfire or electric current or as if by shooting

zapateado.explanation: The rhythmic stamping and tapping of the heels characteristic of Spanish flamenco dances.
A Spanish flamenco dance in which the performer stamps and taps rhythmically with the heels.
A Spanish dance in which the rhythm is marked by blows of the foot on the ground.
A dance of Mexican Indian origin characterized by a lively rhythm punctuated by the striking of the dancer's shoes .

zapatero.explanation: A fish, Oligoplites saurus , found on both coasts of tropical America. See leather-jacket .

zaphrentis.explanation: [ l. c ] A species of this genus.
An extinct genus of cyathophylloid corals common in the Paleozoic formations. It is cup-shaped with numerous septa, and with a deep pit in one side of the cup.

zapote.explanation: The name of a number of fruits more or less spherical in form containing sweet edible pulp, and also of the trees which bear them. Also written sapote . See the following.

zapotecan.explanation: a member of a large tribe of Mesoamericans living in southern Mexico whose civilization flourished around 300 to 900

zapped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zap .

zapping.explanation: The act or result of being zapped.

zaps.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zap .

zapus.explanation: The only genus of Zapodidæ. Z. hudsonius is the common jumping mouse, or deer-mouse, of North America. See cut under deer-mouse .

zarathustrian.explanation: Of or pertaining to Zarathustra, or Zoroaster; Zoroastrian.

zaratite.explanation: A hydrous carbonate of nickel. occurring as an emerald-green incrustation on chromite. Also called emerald nickel .
A hydrous carbonate of nickel occurring as an emerald-green incrustation on chromite; -- called also emerald nickel .
a hydrous basic nickel carbonate occurring in emerald-green incrustations or compact masses

zareba.explanation: An enclosure of bushes or stakes protecting a campsite or village in northeast Africa.
A campsite or village protected by such an enclosure.
In Sudan and adjoining parts of Africa, an inclosure against enemies or wild animals, as by a thorn-hedge; a fortified camp in general. Also written zareeba, zereba, zeriba , etc.
An improvised stockade; especially, one made of thorn bushes, etc.
an improvised stockade constructed especially of thornbushes and used for defense in parts of Africa
a village protected by such a structure

zarf.explanation: A chalicelike holder for a hot coffee cup, typically made of ornamented metal, used in the Middle East.
A metallic cuplike stand used for holding a finjan.
an ornamental container designed to hold a coffee cup and insulate it from the hand of the imbiber
an ornamental metal cup-shaped holder for a hot coffee cup

zariba.explanation: A tall protective hedge , around a village or fortified camp .

zarnec.explanation: A native sulfide of arsenic , including sandarac and orpiment .

zarnich.explanation: An old term embracing the native sulphids of arsenic, sandarac (or realgar) and orpiment.
Native sulphide of arsenic, including sandarach, or realgar, and orpiment.

zarp.explanation: A member of the police force of the late South African Republic; a Boer policeman.

zarzuela.explanation: A short drama with incidental music, like a vaudeville. It is said to have been first introduced into Spain at Zarzuela in the seventeenth century.
A form of Spanish opera having spoken dialogue and usually a comic subject

zastruga.explanation: One of a series of ridges, with corresponding depressions, rising in wave-like succession above the general level of the snow when this has been blown across by a long-continued wind.
Any of a series of long, wavelike ridges or grooves formed on a snow surface by the wind , especially in polar plains .

zastrugi.explanation: Grooves or furrows formed in snow by the action of the wind, and running parallel with the direction of the wind. This formation results from the erosion of transverse waves previously formed.

zati.explanation: The capped macaque of India and Ceylon, Macacus pileolatus.
A species of macaque ( Macacus pileatus ) native of India and Ceylon. It has a crown of long erect hair, and tuft of radiating hairs on the back of the head. Called also capped macaque .
Macacus pileatus, a macaque native to India and Ceylon with a crown of long erect hair.

zauschneria.explanation: A genus of polypetalous plants, of the order Onagrarieæ.
A genus of flowering plants. Zauschneria Californica is a suffrutescent perennial, with showy red flowers much resembling those of the garden fuchsia.
Epilobium canum, a North American willowherb .

zax.explanation: A tool similar to a hatchet, used for cutting and dressing roofing slates.
An instrument used by slaters for cutting and dressing slates; a kind of hatchet with a sharp point on the pole for perforating the slate to receive the nail or pin.
A tool for trimming and puncturing roofing slates.
A tool , similar to a hatchet , used to prepare slate for roofing.

zayat.explanation: A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.
A building in Burma used for meetings and religious assemblies and to give shelter to travellers .

zayin.explanation: The seventh letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
The seventh letter of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding to the English z. Its numerical value is 7.
The seventh letter of many Semitic alphabets ( Phoenician , Aramaic , Hebrew , Syriac , Arabic and others).
the 7th letter of the Hebrew alphabet

zazen.explanation: The primary form of meditation in Zen Buddhism, practiced while sitting cross-legged.
A form of seated meditation in Zen Buddhism.

zeal.explanation: Enthusiastic devotion to a cause, ideal, or goal. synonym : passion .
Passionate ardor in the pursuit of anything; intense interest or endeavor; eagerness to accomplish or obtain some object.
Synonyms Earnestness, Enthusiasm , etc. (see eagerness ), warmth, fervor, heartiness, energy.
Passionate ardor in the pursuit of anything; eagerness in favor of a person or cause; ardent and active interest; engagedness; enthusiasm; fervor.
The fervor or tireless devotion for a person, cause, or ideal and determination in its furtherance; diligent enthusiasm ; powerful interest .
a feeling of strong eagerness (usually in favor of a person or cause)
excessive fervor to do something or accomplish some end

zealander.explanation: a native or inhabitant of Zealand

zealed.explanation: Full of zeal; characterized by zeal.

zealot.explanation: One who is zealous, especially excessively so.
A member of a Jewish movement of the first century AD that fought against Roman rule in Palestine as incompatible with strict monotheism.
One who is zealous or full of zeal; one carried away by excess of zeal; an immoderate partizan: generally in a disparaging sense.

[ capitalized ] One of a fanatical sect or party (the Zelotæ) among the Jews of Palestine under Roman dominion, who on account of their excesses in behalf of the Mosaic law were also called Sicarii or Assassins.

One who is zealous; one who engages warmly in any cause, and pursues his object with earnestness and ardor; especially, one who is overzealous, or carried away by his zeal; one absorbed in devotion to anything; an enthusiast; a fanatical partisan.
One who is zealous , one who is full of zeal for his own specific beliefs or objectives, usually in the negative sense of being too passionate; a fanatic

A member of a radical, warlike, ardently patriotic group of Jews in Judea, particularly prominent in the first century, who advocated the violent overthrow of Roman rule and vigorously resisted the efforts of the Romans and their supporters to convert the Jews.
A member of an anti-aristocratic political group in Thessalonica from 1342 until 1350.
a fervent and even militant proponent of something
a member of an ancient Jewish sect in Judea in the first century who fought to the death against the Romans and who killed or persecuted Jews who collaborated with the Romans

zealotic.explanation: In the manner of a zealot ; zealous ; fanatic .

zealotical.explanation: Like, or suitable to, a zealot; ardently zealous.

zealotism.explanation: The character or conduct of a zealot.
The character or conduct of a zealot; zealotry.
The character or conduct of a zealot ; zealotry .

zealotist.explanation: A zealous partizan; one of a body of zealots.

zealotry.explanation: Behavior as a zealot; excessive or undue zeal; fanaticism.
The character and behavior of a zealot; excess of zeal; fanatical devotion to a cause.
Something characteristic of a zealot ; excessive zeal ; fanaticism .

zealous.explanation: Filled with or motivated by zeal; fervent.
Forward, enthusiastic, fervid, keen. See zeal .
Filled with, or characterized by, zeal; warmly engaged, or ardent, in behalf of an object.
Full of zeal ; ardent , fervent ; exhibiting enthusiasm or strong passion .
marked by active interest and enthusiasm

zealousness.explanation: The quality of being zealous; ardor; zeal.
The quality of being zealous ; zeal .

zeatin.explanation: A cytokinin originally isolated from young corn kernels and found later in various other plants.
A plant hormone derived from adenine , having the chemical formula C10H13N5O.

zeaxanthin.explanation: A xanthophyll carotenoid that occurs naturally in some fruits and vegetables, is found in the retina of the eye, and is an isomer of lutein. It is being investigated as a treatment for macular degeneration.
A yellow crystalline carotenoid alcohol that occurs widely with lutein , with which it is isomeric , and is the chief pigment of maize .
yellow carotenoid (isomeric with lutein and occurs widely with it) that is the main pigment in yellow Indian corn

zebra.explanation: Any of several swift African mammals of the genus Equus, resembling the horse and having distinctive overall markings of alternating white and black or brown stripes.
Any of various striped organisms, such as a zebrafish.
A referee in football.
A name used by fish-culturists in England for hybrids between Salmo fario , the European trout, and Salmo fontinalis , the American brook-trout.

An American heliconiid butterfly, Apostraphia charithonia , with black, yellow-banded wings. It occurs in Central America, the West Indies, and the southern United States. Its larvæ feed on the passion-flower vine.
An African solidungulate mammal, related to the horse and ass, of the genus Equus and subgenus Hippotigris , having the body more or less completely striped.
zebra markings on certain spiders.
Any member of three species of African wild horses remarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, and conspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.

the larva of an American noctuid moth ( Mamestra picta ). It is light yellow, with a broad black stripe on the back and one on each side; the lateral stripes are crossed with withe lines. It feeds on cabbages, beets, clover, and other cultivated plants.
the zebra wolf. See under Wolf .

an Australian grass parrakeet, often kept as a cage bird. Its upper parts are mostly pale greenish yellow, transversely barred with brownish black crescents; the under parts, rump, and upper tail coverts, are bright green; two central tail feathers and the cheek patches are blue. Called also canary parrot , scallop parrot , shell parrot , and undulated parrot .

a poisonous tree ( Euphorbia arborea ) of the Spurge family, found in South Africa. Its milky juice is so poisonous that zebras have been killed by drinking water in which its branches had been placed, and it is also used as an arrow poison.
Same as Tiger shark, under Tiger .
a hunting spider.
a very large North American swallow-tailed butterfly ( Iphiclides ajax ), in which the wings are yellow, barred with black; -- called also ajax .
See under Wolf .
An African animal, closely related to a horse , with black and white stripes .
A referee .

An unlikely diagnosis , especially for symptoms probably caused by a common ailment. (Originates in the advice often given to medical students: "When you hear hoof beats, think of horses, not zebras.")
A bi-racial person, specifically one born to a member of the Sub-Saharan African race and a Caucasian .
any of several fleet black-and-white striped African equines

zebrafish.explanation: A small freshwater fish (Danio rerio) of South Asia that has horizontal dark blue and silvery stripes, is popular in home aquariums, and is used as a model organism in the study of developmental biology and medical genetics.
A small striped fish , Danio rerio, originally from India but now common as an aquarium fish and as a subject of genetic experiments .

zebralike.explanation: Resembling a zebra , especially in having contrasting stripes .

zebrawood.explanation: Any of several African or tropical American trees having striped wood.
The wood of any of these trees, used in cabinetmaking.

The wood of Connarus Guianensis ( Omphalobium Lambertii ), of the Connaraceæ , a tall tree of Guiana; also, the tree itself. The wood is hard and beautifully marked, and is much sought for use in making furniture.
The wood of a small evergreen, Guettarda speciosa , of the Rubiaceæ , found on tropical shores in both hemispheres.
In the West Indies, a shrub or small tree, Myrtus ( Eugenia ) fragrans , var. cuneata.
A kind of cabinet wood having beautiful black, brown, and whitish stripes, the timber of a tropical American tree ( Connarus Guianensis ).
The wood of a small West Indian myrtaceous tree ( Eugenia fragrans ).
The wood of an East Indian tree of the genus Guettarda.
Any wood with a figure ( grain pattern) like the striping of a zebra , most often wood of the genus Microberlinia.
handsomely striped or mottled wood of the zebrawood tree; used especially for cabinetwork
any of various trees or shrubs having mottled or striped wood

zebrina.explanation: Used as a species epithet in botany

zebrine.explanation: Related to, resembling, or characteristic of a zebra.
Hippotigris : correlated with equine and asinine.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the zebra.
of, like or pertaining to a zebra .
A zebra or similar (notably equine ) animal.

zebrinny.explanation: A name given by Professor E. C. Ewart to a hybrid between a stallion and a female zebra.
A cross between a male horse and a female zebra.

zebroid.explanation: The hybrid offspring of a zebra and another equine species, especially a horse.
A hybrid between a zebra and a pony.
A cross between a zebra and any other equine animal, but especially a horse
Of or pertaining to such a cross
Of or pertaining to a zebra; zebrine

zebrula.explanation: An erroneous (New Latin) form of zebrule .
A cross between a male zebra and a female horse.

zebrule.explanation: A name given by Professor E. C. Ewart to the offspring of a mare and a zebra stallion.
A cross between a zebra and a mule .

zebu.explanation: A domesticated ox (Bos indicus syn. B. taurus subsp. indicus) native to Asia and Africa, having a prominent hump on the back and a large dewlap.
The Indian bull, ox, or cow; any individual or breed of Bos indicus , having a hump on the withers.

A bovine mammal ( Ros Indicus ) extensively domesticated in India, China, the East Indies, and East Africa. It usually has short horns, large pendulous ears, slender legs, a large dewlap, and a large, prominent hump over the shoulders; but these characters vary in different domestic breeds, which range in size from that of the common ox to that of a large mastiff.
A domesticated ox native to Asia and Africa, having a large fleshy hump on its back and a dewlap .
domesticated ox having a humped back and long horns and a large dewlap; used chiefly as a draft animal in India and east Asia

zebub.explanation: A large Abyssinian fly noxious to cattle, like the tsetse and the zimb.
A large noxious fly of Abyssinia, which like the tsetse fly, is destructive to cattle.

zecchin.explanation: Any of various gold coins produced in Italy or Turkey; a sequin .

zecchino.explanation: A gold coin of the Venetian republic, worth rather more than 9 s. English, or about $2.25: same as sequin .

zechstein.explanation: In geology , the uppermost of the two divisions of the Permian, the lower being the so-called “Rothliegende.”
The upper division of the Permian (Dyas) of Europe. The prevailing rock is a magnesian limestone.

zed.explanation: The letter Z, also called zee and sometimes izzard .
A metal bar rolled so as to have a cross-section resembling the letter Z.
The letter z ; -- called also zee , and formerly izzard .
The name of the Latin script letter Z / z .
Something Z-shaped. Found in compounds such as zed-bar.
To sleep or nap . (Compare zzz , catch some z's .)
To zigzag ; to move with sharp alternating turns.
the 26th letter of the Roman alphabet

zedoary.explanation: A plant (Curcuma zedoaria) of South Asia that has small yellow flowers, purple bracts, and starchy tuberous rhizomes and that is widely cultivated elsewhere.
The dried rhizomes of this plant, used as a condiment and in perfumes, medicines, and cosmetics.
An East Indian drug, known in two varieties as long and round zedoary.
A medicinal substance obtained in the East Indies, having a fragrant smell, and a warm, bitter, aromatic taste. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.
Curcuma zedoaria, a perennial herb native to India and Indonesia .

zee.explanation: Eye dialect spelling of the , representing primarily French-accented English.
The name of the Latin script letter Z / z .
Something Z-shaped. Found in compounds such as zee-bar.
the 26th letter of the Roman alphabet

zees.explanation: Eye dialect spelling of this , representing primarily French-accented English.

zehner.explanation: An Austrian silver coin equal to ten kreutzers, or about five cents.
An Austrian silver coin equal to ten kreutzers .

zeidae.explanation: a family of fish in the order Zeomorphi

zein.explanation: A prolamine protein derived from corn, used in the manufacture of various plastics, coatings, and lacquers.
A proteid obtained from maize, said to be allied to gluten. It has a yellowish color, and is soft, insipid, and elastic. It differs essentially from the gluten of wheat. Also zeine .
A nitrogenous substance of the nature of gluten, obtained from the seeds of Indian corn ( Zea ) as a soft, yellowish, amorphous substance.
A protein derived from corn / maize , having many industrial applications .

zeitgeist.explanation: The spirit of the age ; the taste , outlook , and spirit characteristic of a period .

zek.explanation: An inmate of a Soviet labor camp.

zelanian.explanation: zoögeog. , of or pertaining to New Zealand: more fully Novo-Zelanian. See New Zealand subregion , under subregion.

zelator.explanation: A zealous partizan or promoter; a zealot.

zelatrix.explanation: A nun who oversees the behaviour of young nuns.

zelkova.explanation: A genus of apetalous trees, of the order Urticaceæ and tribe Celtideæ.
A kind of tree in the elm family (genus Zelkova ).

zelotypia.explanation: The exercise of morbid perseverance and energy in the prosecution of a project, especially one of a political or religious nature; a form of monomania sometimes manifesting itself in overzeal in attempts to gain supporters to any public cause.

zemeism.explanation: That form of religious organization and worship which is associated with zemis. Also zemism .

zemi.explanation: A peculiar kind of image or idol, carved to represent some animal or the human form, found among the aboriginal inhabitants of the islands of the West Indies. They were usually of stone, and are still found occasionally on the islands. They are supposed to represent the ancestor or tutelary god of the clan.
Any of various local deities , human or animal and represented by small idols , once worshipped by the Caribbean peoples of the Taino culture.

zemindar.explanation: Originally, one of a class of farmers of the revenue from land held in common by its cultivators, established by the Mogul government of India, every one in a specially assigned tract or district; now, in many provinces, a native landlord, regarded as a successor of the preceding, and similarly responsible for the land-tax, who under British regulations has become the actual proprietor of the soil under his jurisdiction, often with right of primogeniture.

zemindary.explanation: The office or jurisdiction of a zemindar.

The tract of territory administered or controlled by a zemindar; also, the system of landholding and revenue-collection under zemindars. Also written zamindari, zemindari, zemindaree, zemindarry , etc.

zemmi.explanation: The blind mole-rat, Spalax typhlus. See cut under mole-rat .

zemni.explanation: The blind mole rat ( Spalax typhlus ), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.

zemstvo.explanation: An elective council responsible for the local administration of a provincial district in czarist Russia.
In Russia, a local elective assembly, of recent institution, for the oversight and regulation of affairs within its territory.

In Russia, an elective local district and provincial administrative assembly. Originally it was composed of representatives elected by the peasantry, the householders of the towns, and the landed proprietors. In the reign of Alexander III. the power of the noble landowners was increased, the peasants allowed only to elect candidates from whom the governor of the province nominated the deputy, and all acts of the zemstvo subjected to the approval of the governor. Theoretically the zemstvo has large powers relating to taxation, education, public health, etc., but practically these powers are in most cases limited to the adjustment of the state taxation.
A Russian districtual or provincial conciliary or elective local- governmental administrative division , founded in 1864 by Tsar Alexander the Liberator.

zen.explanation: Pertaining to this denomination of Buddhism

zenaida.explanation: A genus of American ground-doves, typical of the subfamily Zenaidinæ , containing such species as the West Indian Z. amabilis.

zenaidura.explanation: That genus of Columbidæ which contains the Carolina dove, or mourning-dove, Z. carolinensis : so called from the peculiarity of the tail, which has fourteen instead of twelve feathers.

zenana.explanation: The part of a house reserved for the women of the household in South Asia.
In India, that part of the house in which the females of a family are secluded; an East Indian harem.
The part of a dwelling appropriated to women.
A harem on the Indian subcontinent, a part of the house reserved for high-caste women; a system of segregating women into harems.
An effeminate or crossdressing male in northern India or Pakistan.

zendik.explanation: A name given in the East not only to disbelievers in revealed religion, but also to such persons as are accused of magical heresy.
An atheist or unbeliever; -- name given in the East to those charged with disbelief of any revealed religion, or accused of magical heresies.
A heretic or unbeliever , or one who practices heretical magic

zendo.explanation: A hall at a Zen buddhist monastery where formal seated meditation ( zazen ) is practiced.

zenick.explanation: The African suricate, Rhyzæna tetraductyla or Suricata zenick. See cut under suricate .
A South African burrowing mammal ( Suricata tetradactyla ), allied to the civets. It is grayish brown, with yellowish transverse stripes on the back. Called also suricat .

zenith.explanation: The point on the celestial sphere that is directly above the observer.
The upper region of the sky.
The highest point above the observer's horizon attained by a celestial body.
The point of culmination; the peak: synonym : summit .
The vertical point of the heavens at any place, or the point directly above an observer's head; the upper pole of the celestial horizon. The opposed pole is the nadir.
Figuratively, the highest point, or summit, as of one's fortune; the culmination.
That point in the visible celestial hemisphere which is vertical to the spectator; the point of the heavens directly overhead; -- opposed to nadir .
hence, figuratively, the point of culmination; the greatest height; the height of success or prosperity.

a telescope specially designed for determining the latitude by means of any two stars which pass the meridian about the same time, and at nearly equal distances from the zenith, but on opposite sides of it. It turns both on a vertical and a horizontal axis, is provided with a graduated vertical semicircle, and a level for setting it to a given zenith distance, and with a micrometer for measuring the difference of the zenith distances of the two stars.
The point in the sky vertically above a given position or observer; the point in the celestial sphere opposite the nadir .
The highest point in the sky reached by a celestial body .
the point above the observer that is directly opposite the nadir on the imaginary sphere against which celestial bodies appear to be projected

zenithal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the zenith.
Of or pertaining to a zenith
relating to or located at or near the zenith

zenographic.explanation: Measured with reference to the surface of the planet Jupiter .

zenography.explanation: The description and study of the planet Jupiter. Compare selenography, areography.
The study of the planet Jupiter .

zenonian.explanation: b. c. He committed suicide at an advanced age.

zenu.explanation: The goitered antelope, or yellow goat, Procapra gutturosa. See dzeren .

zeolite.explanation: Any one of a family of hydrous alkali-aluminum silicate minerals, whose crystal lattice may enclose or sequester cations of sodium, potassium, magnesium, calcium, strontium, or barium, or a corresponding synthetic compound, used chiefly as molecular filters and ion-exchange agents.
A generic name of a group of hydrated double silicates in which the principal bases are aluminium and calcium or sodium.

A term now used to designate any one of a family of minerals, hydrous silicates of alumina, with lime, soda, potash, or rarely baryta. Here are included natrolite, stilbite, analcime, chabazite, thomsonite, heulandite, and others. These species occur of secondary origin in the cavities of amygdaloid, basalt, and lava, also, less frequently, in granite and gneiss. So called because many of these species intumesce before the blowpipe.
Any of several minerals , aluminosilicates of sodium , potassium , calcium or magnesium , that have a porous structure; they are used in water softeners and in ion exchange chromatography .
any of a family of glassy minerals analogous to feldspar containing hydrated aluminum silicates of calcium or sodium or potassium; formed in cavities in lava flows and in plutonic rocks

zeolitic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a zeolite; consisting of, or resembling, a zeolite.
Of, pertaining to, containing, or produced using a zeolite .

zeolitization.explanation: The process by which a mineral is converted into a zeolite by alteration—for example, nepheline into thomsonite.

zeolitize.explanation: To convert (or be converted) into a zeolite
To fill small cracks with zeolite

zeoscope.explanation: An instrument that was used to determine the alcoholic content of liquid by measuring its boiling point

zep.explanation: A certain type of submarine sandwich

a large sandwich made of a long crusty roll split lengthwise and filled with meats and cheese (and tomato and onion and lettuce and condiments); different names are used in different sections of the United States

zepharovichite.explanation: A hydrous aluminium phosphate, AlPO 4 + 3H 2 O, occurring in whitish crystalline to compact masses: it is found in Bohemia.

zephyr.explanation: Any of various soft light fabrics, yarns, or garments, especially a lightweight, checked gingham fabric.
Something that is airy, insubstantial, or passing.
The west wind; poetically, any soft, mild, gentle breeze.
In entomology , a butterfly of the genus Zephyrus.

A trade-name for a textile fabric or yarn, very fine and light of its kind, and for some other things of similar qualities: chiefly in attributive use: as, zephyr worsted; zephyr crackers (that is, biscuits).
The west wind; poetically, any soft, gentle breeze.
a thin kind of cassimere made in Belgium; also, a waterproof fabric of wool.
a kind of thin, light, embroidered shawl made of worsted and cotton.
a fine, soft kind of yarn or worsted, -- used for knitting and embroidery.
a light wind from the west
any light refreshing wind ; a gentle breeze
any thing of fine, soft , or light quality, especially fabric
(Greek mythology) the Greek god of the west wind

zephyranthes.explanation: A genus of monocotyledonous plants, of the order Amaryllidaceæ and tribe Amarylleæ.

zeppelin.explanation: A rigid airship having a long cylindrical body supported by internal gas cells.

A dirigible balloon of the rigid type, consisting of a cylindrical trussed and covered frame supported by internal gas cells, and provided with means of propulsion and control. It was first successfully used by Ferdinand Count von Zeppelin.
A type of large German dirigible airship of the early 20th century designed to carry passengers or bombs .
a large rigid dirigible designed to carry passengers or bombs
German inventor who designed and built the first rigid motorized dirigible (1838-1917)

zerda.explanation: A small African fox; a fennec. The name is applied to two very different animals:

zero.explanation: The numerical symbol 0; a cipher.
The identity element for addition.
A cardinal number indicating the absence of any or all units under consideration.
An ordinal number indicating an initial point or origin.
An argument at which the value of a function vanishes.
The temperature indicated by the numeral 0 on a thermometer.
A sight setting that enables a firearm to shoot on target.
One having no influence or importance; a nonentity.
The lowest point.
Nothing; nil.
Of, relating to, or being zero.
Having no measurable or otherwise determinable value.
Absent, inoperative, or irrelevant in specified circumstances.
Designating a ceiling not more than 16 meters (52 feet) high.
Limited in horizontal visibility to no more than 55 meters (180 feet).
Of or relating to a morpheme that is expected by an established, regular paradigm but has no spoken or written form. Moose has a zero plural; that is, its plural is moose.
To adjust (an instrument or a device) to zero value.
In function-theory , a value of x which makes the function vanish.
In psychophysics , the temperature at which a thermal stimulus fails to arouse a sensation either of warmth or of cold in the cutaneous organs; the indifference-point of thermal stimulation.
Cipher; the figure 0, which stands for naught in the Arabic notation for numbers.
The defect of all quantity considered as quantity; the origin of measurement stated as at a distance from itself; nothing, quantitatively regarded.
Hence —3. Figuratively, the bottom of the scale; the lowest point or ebb; a state of nullity or inanition.
A cipher; nothing; naught.
The point from which the graduation of a scale, as of a thermometer, commences.
Fig.: The lowest point; the point of exhaustion.
See under Absolute .

a method of comparing, or measuring, forces, electric currents, etc., by so opposing them that the pointer of an indicating apparatus, or the needle of a galvanometer, remains at, or is brought to, zero, as contrasted with methods in which the deflection is observed directly; -- called also null method .
the point indicating zero, or the commencement of a scale or reckoning.
The cardinal number occurring before one and that denotes no quantity or amount at all, represented in Arabic numerals as 0 .
The numeric symbol that represents the cardinal number zero.
The digit 0 in the decimal , binary , and all other base numbering systems.
Nothing , or none .
The value of a magnitude corresponding to the cardinal number zero.
The point on a scale at which numbering or measurement originates.
A value of the independent variables of a function, for which the function is equal to zero.
The additive identity element of a monoid or greater algebraic structure , particularly a group or ring .
A person of little or no importance .
A Mitsubishi A6M Zero, a long range fighter aircraft operated by the Japanese Navy Air Service from 1940 to 1945.
A setting of calibrated instruments such as a firearm .
A security which has a zero coupon (paying no periodic interest).
none

zeroed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zero .

zeroes.explanation: The decade of the 1800s, 1900s, 2000s, etc. The noughties . The 2000s .
Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zero .

zeroize.explanation: To set , reset or initialize something (especially a variable or parameter ) to zero .

zeros.explanation: Plural form of zero . Two or more zero digits.
The decade of the 1800s, 1900s, 2000s, etc. The noughties . The 2000s .

zeroth.explanation: Of or relating to the ordinal number matching the number 0 in a series.
In the first position in a sequence whose elements are numbered starting at zero; the ordinal number corresponding to zero.
Corresponding to a position preceding the first.

zerumbet.explanation: An East Indian drug—according to some, the same as cassumunar. It has sometimes been confounded with the round zedoary.

zest.explanation: Flavor or piquancy.
Interest or excitement.
The outermost part of the rind of an orange, lemon, or other citrus fruit, used as flavoring.
Spirited enjoyment; gusto.
To remove small pieces from (a rind from a citrus fruit) for use as a flavoring in cooking.
The dry woody membrane covering or forming the partitions of a walnut or other nut or fruit, as an orange or a lemon.
A piece of the outer rind of an orange or lemon used as a flavoring or for preserving; also, oil squeezed from such a rind to flavor liquor, etc.
Relish imparted or afforded by anything; piquant nature or quality; agreeableness; charm; piquancy.
Keen relish or enjoyment of anything; stimulated taste or interest; hearty satisfaction; gusto.
To cut into thin slips, as the peel of an orange, lemon, etc.; to squeeze, as peel, over the surface of anything.
To give a relish or flavor to; to heighten the taste or relish of.
A piece of orange or lemon peel, or the aromatic oil which may be squeezed from such peel, used to give flavor to liquor, etc.
Hence, something that gives or enhances a pleasant taste, or the taste itself; an appetizer; also, keen enjoyment; relish; gusto.
The woody, thick skin inclosing the kernel of a walnut.
Enthusiasm .
The outer skin of a citrus fruit , used as a flavouring or garnish .
To scrape the zest from a fruit
To make more zesty
add herbs or spices to
vigorous and enthusiastic enjoyment
a tart spicy quality

zested.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zest .

zestful.explanation: having a spirited love of life ; ebullient

zestfulness.explanation: State or condition of being zestful or enthusiastic .

zestier.explanation: comparative form of zesty : more zesty

zestiest.explanation: superlative form of zesty : most zesty .

zestiness.explanation: The state or property of being zesty .

zests.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zest .

zesty.explanation: having a piquant or pungent taste ; spicy

zeta.explanation: The sixth letter of the Greek alphabet.
A little closet or chamber: applied by some writers to the room over the porch of a Christian church where the porter or sexton lived and kept the church documents.
The sixth letter of the Greek alphabet, corresponding to the English Z.
Z u + Z v − Z ( u + v ) = ksn u. sn verb sn ( u + v ).
A Greek letter [ζ] corresponding to our z.

The name of the sixth letter of the modern Greek alphabet ( Ζ , ζ ) preceded by epsilon ( Ε , ε ) and followed by eta , ( Η , η ); or the seventh letter in the ancient Greek alphabet, in which it is preceded by digamma ( Ϝ , ϝ )
A mathematical function formally known as the Riemann zeta function .
the 6th letter of the Greek alphabet

zetetic.explanation: A seeker: a name adopted by some of the Pyrrhonists.
the method used for finding the value of unknown quantities by direct search, in investigation, or in the solution of problems.
A seeker; -- a name adopted by some of the Pyrrhonists.

zeuglodon.explanation: The typical genus of the family Zeuglodontidæ.
[ lowercase ] A member of this genus; a zeuglodont.
A genus of extinct Eocene whales, remains of which have been found in the Gulf States. The species had very long and slender bodies and broad serrated teeth. See phocodontia .

zeuglodont.explanation: A fossil cetacean of the suborder Zeuglodontia ; a zeuglodon.

zeuglodontia.explanation: A suborder of Cete or Cetacea , represented by the zeuglodonts: sometimes made to consist of two families, the Basilosauridæ (or Zeuglodontidæ ) and Cynorcidæ.

zeugma.explanation: A construction in which one word or phrase is understood to fill a parallel syntactic role in two or more clauses or phrases, as with the verb was in She was upstairs, and her husband downstairs.

A figure in grammar in which two nouns are joined to a verb suitable to only one of them, but suggesting another verb suitable to the other noun; or in which an adjective is similarly used with two nouns.
[ capitalized ] [NL.] In entomology , a genus of hemipterous insects.
A figure by which an adjective or verb, which agrees with a nearer word, is, by way of supplement, referred also to another more remote.
The act of using a word, particularly an adjective or verb, to apply to more than one noun when its sense is appropriate to only one.
use of a word to govern two or more words though appropriate to only one

zeugmatic.explanation: Of or pertaining to zeugma; characterized by zeugma.

zeunerite.explanation: A hydrous arseniate of copper and uranium, occurring in bright-green tetragonal crystals, isomorphous with torbernite.
A mineral with tetragonal crystals, of the autunite group, Cu 2+( U O 2)2( As O4)2·4H2O.

zeuxite.explanation: A ferriferous tourmalin from Cornwall, occurring in acicular interwoven crystals.

zeuzera.explanation: A genus of bombycid moths, of the family Cossidæ , or typical of a family Zeuzeridæ , having the antennæ; of the male unequally pectinate and bare at the tips.

zeuzerian.explanation: Zeuzera ; of or pertaining to the Zeuzeridiæ.
A moth of this genus or family.
Any one of a group of bombycid moths of which the genus Zeuzera is the type. Some of these moths are of large size. The goat moth is an example.

ziamet.explanation: A form of land tenure in the Ottoman Empire .

zibeline.explanation: A thick lustrous soft fabric of wool or other animal hair, such as mohair, having a silky nap.
A kind of woolen dress-goods made from long wool and finished with a furry nap.
A fur, generally thought to be the same as sable.
a thick, soft woolen fabric with a long nap

zibet.explanation: A digitigrade carnivorous quadruped, of the family Viverridæ, Viverra zibetha , a kind of civet found in India and some of the adjacent islands; the Asiatic or Indian civet.

A carnivorous mammal ( Viverra zibetha ) closely allied to the civet, from which it differs in having the spots on the body less distinct, the throat whiter, and the black rings on the tail more numerous.
The large Indian civet , Viverra zibetha.

zibetum.explanation: The odoriferous substance of the zibet; a sort of civet.

ziega.explanation: Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid , after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation .

zietrisikite.explanation: In mineralogy , a mineral resin closely related to ozocerite, found at Zietrisika in Moldavia.
A mineral wax, vert similar to ozocerite. It is found at Zietrisika, Moldavia, whence its name.

zig.explanation: One of a series of sharp turns or reversals.
To turn or change direction suddenly. Usually used in contrast to zag .
To behave erratically or indecisively. Usually used with zag .
A sudden or sharp turn or change of direction .
an angular shape characterized by sharp turns in alternating directions

ziganka.explanation: Music for such a dance, which is quick in pace and usually founded on a drone-bass.

zigged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zig .

ziggurat.explanation: A temple tower of ancient Mesopotamia, having the form of a terraced pyramid of successively receding stories.
A temple tower of the Babylonians or Assyrians, consisting of a lofty pyramidal structure, built in successive stages, with outside staircases, and a shrine at the top; -- called also zikkurat .
A temple tower of the ancient Mesopotamian valley, having the form of a terraced pyramid of successively receding stories.
a rectangular tiered temple or terraced mound erected by the ancient Assyrians and Babylonians

zigs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zig .

zigzag.explanation: A line or course that proceeds by sharp turns in alternating directions.
One of a series of such sharp turns.
Something, such as a road or design, that exhibits one or a series of sharp turns.
Moving in or having a zigzag.
In a zigzag manner or pattern.
To move in or form a zigzag.
To cause to move in or form a zigzag.
A sharp turning back and forth or in and out; an irregular, abrupt angulation; one of a series of sharp turns in a linear or curvilinear course: nearly always in the plural.
A formation with a succession of sharp turnings or angles; something that has a number of abrupt angulations, like those of chain-lightning.
Specifically
A winding path with sharp turns, as up the side of a steep mountain.
In fortification , a trench of approach against a fortress, so constructed that the line of trench may not be enfiladed by the defenders: same as boyau .
In architecture , same as chevron , 2.
In the fisheries , a salmon-stair or fish way.
In entomology , a British moth, Bombyx dispar.
botany , angularly bent from side to side.
To form with short turns.
Having short, sharp turns; running this way and that in an onward course.
To move in a zigzag manner; also, to have a zigzag shape.
Something that has short turns or angles.
A molding running in a zigzag line; a chevron, or series of chevrons. See Illust. of Chevron , 3.
See Boyau .
a line or path that proceeds by sharp turns in alternating directions
one of such sharp turns
Moving in, or having a zigzag.
to move in a zigzag manner
in a zigzag manner or pattern
having short sharp turns or angles

having short sharp turns or angles

zigzagged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zigzag .

zigzaggedness.explanation: The state or quality of being zigzagged or alternating directions sharply .

zigzaggery.explanation: The character of being zigzag; angular crookedness.
The quality or state of being zigzag; crookedness.
The quality or state of being zigzag ; crookedness .

zigzags.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zigzag .

a rectangular tiered temple or terraced mound erected by the ancient Assyrians and Babylonians

zilch.explanation: A person regarded as being insignificant; a nonentity.

zill.explanation: One of a pair of round metal cymbals attached to the fingers and struck together for rhythm and percussion in belly dancing.
one of a pair of small metallic cymbals worn on the thumb and middle finger; used in belly dancing in rhythm with the dance

zilla.explanation: A low, thorny, suffrutescent, crucifeous plant ( Zilla myagroides ) found in the deserts of Egypt. Its leaves are boiled in water, and eaten, by the Arabs.

zillah.explanation: In Hindustan, an administrative division of a province.
A district or local division, as of a province.
A district or local division , as of a province , in India .

zillion.explanation: a very large indefinite number (usually hyperbole)

zillionth.explanation: The ordinal form of the number zillion .
The person or thing in the zillionth position.
One of a zillion equal parts of a whole.

zimarra.explanation: a cassock with a small cape attached

zimb.explanation: A dipterous insect of Abyssinia, resembling and related to the tsetse of southern Africa, and very destructive to cattle.
A large, venomous, two-winged fly, native of Abyssinia. It is allied to the tsetse fly, and, like the latter, is destructive to cattle.
An Ethiopian horsefly of the genus Pangonia, destructive to livestock .

zimbabwe.explanation: Any of the prominent cultural ruins of which Greater Zimbabwe is the most well known.

zimbi.explanation: A money-cowry, as Cypræa moneta. See cut under cowry .

zimocca.explanation: A kind of commercial sponge, Euspongia zimocca , a bath-sponge of fine quality.
A sponge ( Euspongia zimocca ) of flat form and fine quality, from the Adriatic, about the Greek islands, and the coast of Barbary.

zinc.explanation: A bluish-white, lustrous metallic element that is brittle at room temperature but malleable with heating. It is used to form a wide variety of alloys including brass, bronze, various solders, and nickel silver, in galvanizing iron and other metals, for electric fuses, anodes, meter cases and batteries, and in roofing, gutters, and various household objects. US pennies minted after 1982 consist of a copper-clad zinc core. Atomic number 30; atomic weight 65.38; melting point 419.53°C; boiling point 907°C; specific gravity 7.134 (at 25°C); valence 2. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
To coat or treat with zinc; galvanize.
The zinc element of a galvanic cell, prepared of proper shape and size, and often fitted with a binding-screw, ready for use.
Chemical symbol, Zn; atomic weight, 64.9. One of the useful metals, more tenacious than lead and tin, but malleable only at a temperature between 200° and 250° F.
To coat with zinc; to galvanize.

An abundant element of the magnesium-cadmium group, extracted principally from the minerals zinc blende, smithsonite, calamine, and franklinite, as an easily fusible bluish white metal, which is malleable, especially when heated. It is not easily oxidized in moist air, and hence is used for sheeting, coating galvanized iron, etc. It is used in making brass, britannia, and other alloys, and is also largely consumed in electric batteries. Symbol Zn. Atomic number 30. Atomic weight 65.38.
zinc chloride, ZnCl2, a deliquescent white waxy or oily substance.
See Zinc oxide, below.
a white amorphous substance, Zn(NH2)2, obtained by the action of ammonia on zinc ethyl; -- called also zinc amide .
a colorless, transparent liquid, composed of zinc and amyle, which, when exposed to the atmosphere, emits fumes, and absorbs oxygen with rapidity.
a native zinc sulphide. See Blende , n. (a).
hydrous carbonate of zinc, usually occurring in white earthy incrustations; -- called also hydrozincite .
a colorless, transparent, poisonous liquid, composed of zinc and ethyl, which takes fire spontaneously on exposure to the atmosphere.
a green pigment consisting of zinc and cobalt oxides; -- called also Rinmann's green .

a colorless mobile liquid Zn(CH3)2, produced by the action of methyl iodide on a zinc sodium alloy. It has a disagreeable odor, and is spontaneously inflammable in the air. It has been of great importance in the synthesis of organic compounds, and is the type of a large series of similar compounds, as zinc ethyl , zinc amyle , etc.

the oxide of zinc, ZnO, forming a light fluffy sublimate when zinc is burned; -- called also flowers of zinc , philosopher's wool , nihil album , etc. The impure oxide produced by burning the metal, roasting its ores, or in melting brass, is called also pompholyx , and tutty .
a mineral, related to spinel, consisting essentially of the oxides of zinc and aluminium; gahnite.
zinc sulphate. See White vitriol, under Vitriol .
a white powder consisting of zinc oxide, used as a pigment.
a chemical element (symbol Zn) with an atomic number of 30.
To electroplate with zinc.
To coat with sunblock incorporating zinc oxide .
coat or cover with zinc

a bluish-white lustrous metallic element; brittle at ordinary temperatures but malleable when heated; used in a wide variety of alloys and in galvanizing iron; it occurs naturally as zinc sulphide in zinc blende

zincate.explanation: Any of various salts containing ZnO 2 2− or related hydroxide complexes, such as Zn(OH) 3 − .

In chem. , a compound which may be viewed as resulting from the union of zinc oxid with the oxid of a more electropositive metal, or from the replacement of hydrogen in zinc hydroxid by a very strongly electropositive metal, such as potassium or sodium.
any salt formally derived from zinc oxide or hydroxide by combination with a more electropositive element

zinced.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zinc .

zincic.explanation: Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, zinc; zincous.
Containing, resembling or pertaining to zinc .

zincide.explanation: In chem. , a compound of zinc with a more electropositive element or radical, as with sodium.

zincification.explanation: The act or process of applying zinc; the condition of being zincified, or covered with zinc; galvanization.
The act or process of zincifying .

zincified.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zincify .

zincifies.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zincify .

zincify.explanation: To coat or impregnate with zinc.
To coat or impregnate with zinc .

zincing.explanation: process ); also the operation of adding zinc to the lead bath in the Parkes process.

zincite.explanation: A red to yellow-orange zinc ore, ZnO.
Native zinc oxide; a brittle, translucent mineral, of an orange-red color; -- called also red zinc ore , and red oxide of zinc .
A yellow, orange or dark-red mineral form of zinc oxide , often also containing small amounts of manganese, with a chemical formula ( Zn , Mn 2+) O , an important ore of zinc.

zincked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zinc .

zinckenite.explanation: A steel-gray mineral consisting of the sulphids of antimony and lead.

zincking.explanation: The act of coating iron with a weak solution of sulphate of zinc, or ore of the double salts of chlorid of zinc and sal ammoniac.
The act or process of applying zinc; galvanization.

zincky.explanation: Pertaining to zinc, or having its appearance.

zincode.explanation: The negative pole of a voltaic battery; the anode of an electrolytic cell.
The positive electrode of an electrolytic cell; anode.
The positive electrode of an electrolytic cell ; the anode .

zincograph.explanation: A prepared zinc plate used in zincography.
A print or picture obtained from a zincograph.
A plate or a picture produced by zincography. Also zincotype .
A zinc plate prepared for printing by zincography; also, a print from such a plate.
An engraved zinc plate used in zincography .
An engraving made with such a plate.

zincography.explanation: The process of engraving zinc printing plates.
The art of producing on zinc a printing surface in relief by etching with dilute acid the unprotected parts of the plate. Compare paniconography .
The art or process of engraving or etching on zinc, in which the design is left in relief in the style of a wood cut, the rest of the ground being eaten away by acid.
A lithographic method of producing engravings using zinc plates

zincoid.explanation: Pertaining to, or resembling, zinc; -- said of the electricity of the zincous plate in connection with a copper plate in a voltaic circle; also, designating the positive pole.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling zinc
Of or pertaining to the zinc electrode that connects to a copper one in a voltaic cell

zincolysis.explanation: A mode of decomposition occasioned by an electrical current; electrolysis.

zincous.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or containing, zinc; zincic.
Hence, formerly, basic, basylous, as opposed to chlorous .
Of or pertaining to the positive pole of a galvanic battery; electro-positive.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, zinc .

zincs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zinc .

zincum.explanation: A Latinized form of the name of the metal zinc. Used in official medical terminology.

zineb.explanation: An organic fungicide and insecticide sprayed on cereal grasses, fruit trees, etc.

zinfandel.explanation: A dry red wine of California .
A small black grape from which zinfandel wine is made.

zing.explanation: A brief high-pitched humming or buzzing sound, such as that made by a swiftly passing object or a taut vibrating string.
To move swiftly with or as if with a zing.
A short high-pitched humming sound, eg that made by a bullet or vibrating string.
To move very quickly, especially while making a high-pitched hum.
Used to acknowledge a witty comeback , a zinger.
the activeness of an energetic personality
a brief high-pitched buzzing or humming sound

zinged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zing .

zingel.explanation: A fish of the family Percidæ and genus Aspro ; specifically, A. zingel of the Danube and its tributaries.
A small, edible, freshwater European perch ( Aspro zingel ), having a round, elongated body and prominent snout.

zinger.explanation: A sudden shock, revelation, or turn of events.
A very rapidly moving object, especially one that is thrown .
A surprising or unusually pointed or telling remark.
An event that when experienced leaves the witness dazed , either physically or metaphorically.
An outstanding, energetic and surprising thing or person.
a striking or amusing or caustic remark

zingerone.explanation: A crystalline solid organic compound that gives ginger its pungent taste.

zingiber.explanation: A genus of plants, type of the order Zingiberaceæ and of the tribe Zingibereæ.
Any member of the genus Zingiber of gingers .
tropical Asiatic and Polynesian perennial plants: ginger

zingiberaceae.explanation: a family of tropical monocotyledonous plants of order Musales

zingiberene.explanation: A monocyclic sesquiterpene , the predominant constituent of the oil of ginger .

zingier.explanation: comparative form of zingy : more zingy

zingiest.explanation: superlative form of zingy : most zingy .

zings.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zing .

zinke.explanation: In organ-building , a loud reed-stop. Also cornet .
A small cornet of wood or horn, once very common in Germany.

zinked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zinc .

zinkenite.explanation: A dark gray mineral, Pb 6 Sb 14 S 27 .
A steel-gray metallic mineral, a sulphide of antimony and lead.
A grey mineral with hexagonal crystals, Pb 9 Sb 22 S 42.
a steel grey metallic mineral (a sulphide of lead and antimony)

zinnia.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Zinnia of the composite family, native to tropical America and widely cultivated for their showy, colorful flower heads.
A genus of composite plants, of the tribe Helianthoideæ , type of the subtribe Zinnieæ.
[ lowercase ] A plant of this genus.
Any plant of the composite genus Zinnia, Mexican herbs with opposite leaves and large gay-colored blossoms. Zinnia elegans is the commonest species in cultivation.
Any of several brightly coloured flowering plants , of the genus Zinnia , native to tropical America ; old maid
any of various plants of the genus Zinnia cultivated for their variously and brightly colored flower heads

zinnwaldite.explanation: A kind of mica related to lepidolite, but containing both lithium and iron: it is often found associated with tin ores, as at Zinnwald in the Erzgebirge.
A kind of mica containing lithium, often associated with tin ore.
A mineral with monoclinic crystals, K Li Fe 2+ Al (Al Si 3) O 10( F ,O H )2, of the mica group.
a mica containing iron and lithium

zinziberaceous.explanation: Belonging to the ginger family, and of the genus name Zingiber ; zingiberaceous .

zionist.explanation: Specifically, an adherent of the plan of colonizing Hebrews in Palestine set forth by Theodor Herzl in 1896. See Zionism .
relating to or characteristic of a supporter of Zionism
relating to or characteristic of Zionism

zip.explanation: A brief sharp hissing sound.
Energy; vim.
A zipper.
Nothing; nil; zero.
To move with a sharp hissing sound.
To move or act with a speed that suggests such a sound.
To act or proceed swiftly and energetically.
To become fastened or unfastened by a zipper.
To cause to move with speed and force.
To fasten or unfasten with a zipper.
The sound of a bullet passing through the air or striking against an object.
A hissing or sibilant sound such as that made by a flying bullet.
To make, or move with, such a sound.
Shortened form of ZIP code , the US postal code.
Any postal code , for any country.
The high-pitched sound of a small object moving rapidly through air.
Energy; vigor; vim
A zip fastener .
Zero; nothing
A trip on a zipline
The high-pitched sound of a small object moving rapidly through air.
To close with a zip fastener .
To close as if with a zip fastener.
To compress (one or more computer files) into a single and often smaller file, especially one in the ZIP format.
(followed by a preposition) To move rapidly (in a specified direction or to a specified place) with a high-pitched sound.
(followed by a preposition) To move in haste (in a specified direction or to a specified place).
To make (something) move quickly
To travel on a zipline .
a quantity of no importance
close with a zipper
a code of letters and digits added to a postal address to aid in the sorting of mail
forceful exertion
move very fast
a fastener for locking together two toothed edges by means of a sliding tab

ziphiidae.explanation: beaked whales; in some especially former classifications included in the family Physeteridae

ziphioid.explanation: Any member of the Ziphiidæ or Ziphiinæ. Also written xiphioid .

ziphius.explanation: A genus of odontocete cetaceans, or toothed whales, taken as type of the Ziphiinæ : used with varying restrictions, and in some acceptations synonymous with Mesoplodon.
[ lowercase ] A whale of this genus.

zipped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zip .

zippeite.explanation: A basic sulphate of uranium, occurring in delicate needle-like crystals of a bright-yellow color: it is found at Joachimsthal.

A hydrous potassium uranium sulfate mineral with chemical formula K4(UO2)6(SO4)3(OH)10·4(H2O), forming yellow to reddish-brown monoclinic - prismatic crystals with perfect cleavage and formerly used in the manufacture of paint .

zipper.explanation: A fastening device consisting of parallel rows of metal or plastic teeth on adjacent edges of an opening that are interlocked by a sliding tab.
To fasten or unfasten or become fastened or unfastened with a zipper; zip.
To put a zipper on an article.
a fastener for locking together two toothed edges by means of a sliding tab

zippered.explanation: Having or equipped with zippers or a zipper.
Closed or fastened with or as if with a zipper.
Simple past tense and past participle of zipper .

zippier.explanation: comparative form of zippy : more zippy

zippiest.explanation: superlative form of zippy : most zippy .

ziram.explanation: A zinc salt C6H12N2S4Zn used as a fungicide .

zircaloy.explanation: Any of a set of specialist alloys of zirconium

zircofluoride.explanation: A double fluoride of zirconium and hydrogen, or some other positive element or radical.
A double fluoride of zirconium and hydrogen , or some other positive element or radical.

zircon.explanation: A brown to colorless mineral, ZrSiO 4 , which is heated, cut, and polished to form a brilliant blue-white gem.
A mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of adamantine luster and yellowish to brownish or reddish color: its hardness is somewhat greater than that of quartz.

A mineral consisting predominantly of zirconium silicate (Zr2SiO4) occurring in tetragonal crystals, usually of a brown or gray color. It consists of silica and zirconia. A red variety, used as a gem, is called hyacinth . Colorless, pale-yellow or smoky-brown varieties from Ceylon are called jargon .
an imitation gemstone made of cubic zirconia.
a coarse-grained syenite containing zircon crystals and often also elæolite. It is largely developed in Southern Norway.
A mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals, usually of a brown or grey colour and consisting of silica and zirconia .
A crystal of zircon, sometimes used as a false gemstone.
a common mineral occurring in small crystals; chief source of zirconium; used as a refractory when opaque and as a gem when transparent

zirconia.explanation: An oxid, ZrO, of the metal zirconium, resembling alumina in appearance. It is so hard as to scratch glass.

This earth is now of industrial value as the chief material used in the ‘glower’ of the Nernst incandescent electric lamp. The glower commonly consists of about 85 per cent. zirconia and 15 per cent. yttria or mixed earths of that class.

The oxide of zirconium (ZrO2), obtained as a white powder, and possessing both acid and basic properties. On account of its infusibility, and brilliant luminosity when incandescent, it is used as an ingredient of sticks for the Drummomd light.
A colorless form of zirconia similar in appearance and refractivity to diamond, and used as a substitute for diamonds in inexpensive jewelry; -- also known by the acronym CZ .

The oxide of zirconium , obtained as a white powder, and possessing both acid and basic properties. On account of its infusibility , and brilliant luminosity when incandescent , it is used as an ingredient of sticks for the Drummond light .
a white crystalline oxide; used in refractories and in insulation and abrasives and enamels and glazes

zirconic.explanation: Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, zirconium
an acid of zirconium analogous to carbonic and silicic acids, known only in its salts.

zirconium.explanation: A lustrous, grayish-white, strong, ductile metallic element obtained primarily from zircon and used in nuclear reactors because of its high resistance to corrosion, used in ceramic and refractory compounds, and alloyed with niobium, zinc, and other metals.
