Atomic number 40; atomic weight 91.22; melting point 1,855°C; boiling point 4,409°C; specific gravity 6.52 (at 20°C); valence 2, 3, 4. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, Zr; atomic weight, 89.6. The metal contained in zirconia.

A rare element of the carbon-silicon group, intermediate between the metals and nonmetals, obtained from the mineral zircon as a dark sooty powder, or as a gray metallic crystalline substance. Symbol Zr. Atomic weight, 90.4.
a metallic chemical element (symbol Zr) with an atomic number of 40.
a lustrous grey strong metallic element resembling titanium; it is used in nuclear reactors as a neutron absorber; it occurs in baddeleyite but is obtained chiefly from zircon

zirconoid.explanation: In crystallography , a double eight-sided pyramid belonging to the tetragonal system: so called because it is a common form with zircon.
A double eight-sided pyramid, a form common with tetragonal crystals; -- so called because this form often occurs in crystals of zircon.
A double eight-sided pyramid , a form common with tetragonal crystals ; — so called because this form often occurs in crystals of zircon .

zirconyl.explanation: The oxygenated cation of zirconium ZrO2+

zirkelite.explanation: In petrography , a name applied by Wadsworth (1887) to diabasic glasses. Same as sordavalite .
A rare mineral containing zirconium, titanium, thorium, iron, and calcium. It occurs in black octahedral crystals at Jacupiranga, Brazil.
An isometric oxide mineral with the chemical formula (Ca,Th,Ce)Zr(Ti,Nb)2O7.

zit.explanation: a small inflamed elevation of the skin; a pustule or papule; common symptom in acne

zither.explanation: A musical instrument composed of a flat sound box with about 30 to 40 strings stretched over it and played horizontally with the fingertips, a plectrum, or a bow, or set into vibration by the wind, as in the Aeolian harp.

An instrument of music used in Austria and Germany. It has from thirty to forty wires strung across a shallow sounding-board, which lies horizontally on a table before the performer, who uses both hands in playing on it. [Not to be confounded with the old lute-shaped cittern , or cithern .]

A musical instrument consisting of a flat sounding box with numerous strings , placed on a horizontal surface, and played with a plectrum and fingertips; similar to a dulcimer . In the Norwegian harpeleik and Swedish cittra versions, the instrument is considered a chorded zither and usually has 7 (Norwegian) to 9 (Swedish) chords, some with as many as 11 strings each, which are mostly strummed and damped as chords, although sometimes plucked. The Norwegian harpeleik and Swedish cittra are still in production by a German manufacturer.
a musical stringed instrument with strings stretched over a flat sounding board; it is laid flat and played with a plectrum and with fingers

zithern.explanation: a musical stringed instrument with strings stretched over a flat sounding board; it is laid flat and played with a plectrum and with fingers

ziti.explanation: Pasta in medium-sized, often ridged tubes.
A type of penne pasta which resembles mostaccioli .
medium-sized tubular pasta in short pieces

zizania.explanation: Any of several aquatic North American grasses , of the genus Zizania , grown for its edible grain ; wild rice

zizith.explanation: The tassels of twisted cords or threads on the corners of the upper garment worn by strict Jews. The Hebrew for this word is translated in both the Authorized and Revised Versions (Deut. xxii. 12) by the word “fringes.”

zizyphus.explanation: A genus of polypetalous plants, of the order Rhamnaceæ , type of the tribe Zizypheæ.

zloty.explanation: złoty , the currency unit of Poland , divided into 100 groszy .
the basic unit of money in Poland

zoaea.explanation: A larval stage of development in crustaceans , especially decapods such as crabs, characterized by spines on the carapace and rudimentary thoracic and abdominal limbs.

zoanthacea.explanation: A suborder of Actiniaria , containing permanently attached forms, as Zoanthus and related genera.
A suborder of Actinaria, including Zoanthus and allied genera, which are permanently attached by their bases.

zoantharian.explanation: A member of the Zoantharia , as a seaanemone.
Of or pertaining to the Zoantharia.
Of or pertaining to the Zoantharia .

zoanthid.explanation: Any member of the order Zoanthidea of cnidarians commonly found in coral reefs and other marine environments.

zoanthodeme.explanation: A compound zoantharian; the whole organism constituted by the coherent zoöids produced by the budding of a single actinozoan polyp.
The zooids of a compound anthozoan, collectively.
The zooids of a compound anthozoan , collectively.

zoanthoid.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Zoanthacea.
Of or pertaining to the Zoanthacea .

zoanthropy.explanation: A form of insanity in which a person believes himself to be one of the lower animals.
A kind of monomania in which the patient believes himself transformed into one of the lower animals.
A kind of delusion in which the patient believes himself transformed into one of the lower animals .
the delusion that you have assumed the form of an animal

zoanthus.explanation: A genus of Actinaria, including numerous species, found mostly in tropical seas. The zooids or polyps resemble small, elongated actinias united together at their bases by fleshy stolons, and thus forming extensive groups. The tentacles are small and bright colored.

zoarces.explanation: The name-giving genus of Zoarcidæ , including such species as Z. viviparus , the so-called viviparous blenny (formerly Blennius viviparus ).

zoarium.explanation: The aggregate of zooids that make up a colonial organism such as a bryozoan.
A polyzoary; the colony or aggregate of the polypides of a polyzoan; the polypidom or polypary of the moss-animalcules.

zobo.explanation: A breed of zebu-cattle, supposed to be a hybrid of the common zebu with the yak, reared in the western Himalayan region for its flesh and milk, and also as a beast of burden.
A kind of domestic cattle reared in Asia for its flesh and milk. It is supposed to be a hybrid between the zebu and the yak.
A kind of Asian cattle , supposed to be a hybrid between the zebu and yak .

zocalo.explanation: A town square or plaza, especially in Mexico.
A town square or marketplace, especially in Mexico.

zodiac.explanation: A band of the celestial sphere extending about 8° to either side of the ecliptic that represents the path of the principal planets, the moon, and the sun.

In astrology, this band divided into 12 equal parts called signs, each 30° wide, bearing the name of a constellation for which it was originally named but with which it no longer coincides owing to the precession of the equinoxes.
A diagram or figure representing the zodiac.
Of the moon or of a planet, the belt of the heavens within which the moon or a planet moves.
A belt of twelve constellations, extending about 8° on each side of the ecliptic.
Figuratively, a round or circuit; a zone; a complete course.
In heraldry , a bearing representing a part of the imaginary zodiacal circle, forming an arched bend or bend sinister, and with several of the signs upon it, the number being specified in the blazon.

An imaginary belt in the heavens, 16° or 18° broad, in the middle of which is the ecliptic, or sun's path. It comprises the twelve constellations, which one constituted, and from which were named, the twelve signs of the zodiac.
A figure representing the signs, symbols, and constellations of the zodiac.
The belt-like region of the celestial sphere approximately eight degrees north and south of the ecliptic , which thousands of years ago included the apparent path of the sun , moon , and planets .
The twelve equal divisions of the astrological zodiacal region into signs , or houses , of the zodiac, each sign named after a constellation in this region.
The belt-like region of the celestial sphere corresponding to the apparent path of the sun over the course of a year, the ecliptic .
A circle decorated with the signs of the zodiac.
Any of various astrological systems considered similar to the above.
(astrology) a circular diagram representing the 12 zodiacal constellations and showing their signs
a belt-shaped region in the heavens on either side to the ecliptic; divided into 12 constellations or signs for astrological purposes

zodiacal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the zodiac; situated within the zodiac.

a luminous tract of the sky, of an elongated, triangular figure, lying near the ecliptic, its base being on the horizon, and its apex at varying altitudes. It is to be seen only in the evening, after twilight, and in the morning before dawn. It is supposed to be due to sunlight reflected from multitudes of meteoroids revolving about the sun nearly in the plane of the ecliptic.
of or pertaining to the zodiac
relating to or included in the zodiac

zodiophilous.explanation: botany , animal-loving: applied to those flowers which from their structure are especially adapted for fertilization by insects: it is the converse of anthophilous , said of the insects concerned.

zoea.explanation: A larval form of crabs and certain other decapod crustaceans, characterized by thoracic appendages used for swimming and often one or more spines on the carapace.

zoetrope.explanation: A mechanical device consisting of a rotating drum ringed with narrow apertures through which an animated image is viewed.
An optical instrument which exhibits pictures as if alive and in action, depending, like the thaumatrope, the phenakistoscope, etc., on the persistence of vision.

An optical toy, in which figures made to revolve on the inside of a cylinder, and viewed through slits in its circumference, appear like a single figure passing through a series of natural motions as if animated or mechanically moved.

An optical toy, in which figures made to revolve on the inside of a cylinder, and viewed through slits in its circumference, appear like a single figure passing through a series of natural motions as if animated or mechanically moved.

zoetropic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or reminiscent of a zoetrope .

zoftig.explanation: (of a female body) healthily plump and vigorous

zogan.explanation: Inlaid work of gold or silver in other metal, as practised by the Japanese.

zoic.explanation: Of or pertaining to animals, or animal life.
Showing traces of life; containing organic remains.
Having the form of an animal; animal-like, zoomorphic .
pertaining to animals or animal life or action

zoidogamous.explanation: botany , fertilized by motile male cells, or spermatozoids: said of the higher cryptogams among plants.

zoilean.explanation: b. c. ), noted for his severe criticism of Homer; having the character of Zoilism.
Having the characteristic of Zoilus, a bitter, envious, unjust critic, who lived about 270 years before Christ.

zoilism.explanation: Criticism like that of Zoilus; illiberal or carping criticism; unjust censure.
Resemblance to Zoilus in style or manner; carping criticism; detraction.

zoilist.explanation: An imitator of Zoilus; one who practises Zoilism; a carping critic.

zoilus.explanation: A critic characterized as bitter , carping , malignant .

zoisite.explanation: A gray, brown, pink, or blue mineral, Ca 2 Al 3 (SiO 4 ) 3 (OH), used in ornamental stonework.
A mineral closely related to epidote, but orthorhombic in crystallization.
A grayish or whitish mineral occurring in orthorhombic, prismatic crystals, also in columnar masses. It is a silicate of alumina and lime, and is allied to epidote.
A mineral with orthorhombic crystals, Ca 2 Al 3( Si O 4)(Si2O7)O(O H ).

zoisitization.explanation: In petrography , the alteration of minerals or rocks to zoisite.

zoism.explanation: The doctrine that the phenomena of life depend upon a peculiar vital principle; any vitalistic theory.
Reverence for animal life or belief in animal powers and influences, as among savages.
A doctrine, now discarded, that the phenomena of life are due to a peculiar vital principle; the theory of vital force.

zoist.explanation: One who studies the phenomena of life from the standpoint of zoism; one who upholds the theory or doctrine of zoism. See zoism .

zokor.explanation: An Asiatic burrowing rodent ( Siphneus aspalax ) resembling the mole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent , resembling the mole rat , native to the Altai Mountains.

zolaesque.explanation: In the style of Zola (see zolaism ).
in the manner of Emile Zola

zolaism.explanation: The characteristic quality of the works of Emile Zola (born 1840), a French novelist characterized by an excessively “realistic” treatment of the grosser phases of life; coarse “realism” or “naturalism.”
The literary theories and practices of the French novelist Emile Zola (1840-1902); naturalism, esp. in a derogatory sense.

zolaist.explanation: A writer whose works are marked by Zolaism; a literary follower of Émile Zola.

zoll.explanation: The twelfth part of a German foot, varying with the length of the foot but not very different from the English inch.

zollpfund.explanation: The pound adopted for the customs service of the German Zollverein, equal to 500 grams, or 1.1023 pounds avoirdupois.

zolotnik.explanation: A Russian unit of weight, of the funt or Russian pound, equal to 4.27 grams or nearly 66 grains. It is divided into 96 dolia.

zombi.explanation: someone who acts or responds in a mechanical or apathetic way
(voodooism) a spirit or supernatural force that reanimates a dead body
a god of voodoo cults of African origin worshipped especially in West Indies
a dead body that has been brought back to life by a supernatural force
several kinds of rum with fruit juice and usually apricot liqueur

zombie.explanation: In voodoo belief and popular folklore, a corpse that has been reanimated, especially by means of a supernatural power or spell.
One who looks or behaves like an automaton.
A computer connected to the internet and controlled by a remote unauthorized user to perform malicious tasks, without the owner being aware.
A bank or business that cannot meet its financial obligations or make new loans but has been allowed to continue operating by the government.
A snake god of voodoo cults in West Africa, Haiti, and the southern United States.
A tall mixed drink made of various rums, liqueur, and fruit juice.
A snake god or fetish in religions of West Africa and elsewhere.
A person, usually undead , animated by unnatural forces (such as magic ), with no soul or will of his/her own.
A deceased person who becomes reanimate to attack the living .
An apathetic person.
A human being in a state of extreme mental exhaustion .
A process or task which has terminated but was not removed from the list of processes, typically because it has child processes that have not yet terminated.
A computer affected by malware which causes it to do whatever the attacker wants it to do without the user's knowledge.
A cocktail of rum and fruit juices .
A hypothetical person who lacks self awareness.
a god of voodoo cults of African origin worshipped especially in West Indies
a dead body that has been brought back to life by a supernatural force
(voodooism) a spirit or supernatural force that reanimates a dead body
several kinds of rum with fruit juice and usually apricot liqueur
someone who acts or responds in a mechanical or apathetic way

zombiism.explanation: The condition of being a zombie .

zomotherapy.explanation: Use of raw meat, or the juice expressed therefrom, in the treatment of disease.
a regimen of medical treatment that involves prescribing a diet of raw meat in order to fight a disease.

zona.explanation: In anatomy , a zone, belt, or girdle, or part likened to a zone: chiefly used in human anatomy.
A zone or band; a layer.
a radiately striated membrane situated next the yolk of an ovum, or separated from it by a very delicate membrane only.
A species of silverside fish ( Atheriniformes ), Bedotia geayi, from Madagascar , also called red-tailed silverside.
A zone or band ; a layer .

zonal.explanation: phytogeography , in or relating to œcological zones or belts. See zonc , 8.
zonal symmetry, the serial homology or metameric symmetry of a segmented animal, as an arthropod or an annelid. See symmetry , 5 .
crystallography , arranged in zones: as, the zonal structure of a mineral.
botany , noting that view of a diatom in which the zone or suture of the valves is presented to the eye—the “front view” of some writers.
horticulture , marked on the leaves with a zone or circle, as many pelargoniums, also called horscshoe geraniums.
Of or pertaining to a zone; having the form of a zone or zones.
the mathematical relation which belongs to all the planes of a zone, and expresses their common position with reference to the axes.

a structure characterized by the arrangements of color, inclusions, etc., of a crystal in parallel or concentric layers, which usually follow the outline of the crystal, and mark the changes that have taken place during its growth.
Related to, associated with, or similar to zones .
Roughly longitudinal movement of air or ocean currents (east to west, or west to east).
associated with or divided into zones
relating to or of the nature of a zone

zonality.explanation: The state or condition of being zonal .

zonally.explanation: in a manner related to, associated with, or similar to zones .

zonar.explanation: A belt or girdle which the Christians and Jews of the Levant were obliged to wear to distinguish them from Mohammedans.

zonaria.explanation: A small genus of widely distributed phæosporous algæ, of the order Dictyotaceæ , having a more or less fan-shaped frond obscurely marked with concentric zones, and roundish or linear sori formed beneath the cuticle of the frond.
One of two primary groups (the other being Discoidea ) into which Huxley divided the deciduate Mammalia , consisting of those Deciduata which have a zonary placenta; the Zonoplacentalia.
A division of Mammalia in which the placenta is zonelike.

zonary.explanation: relating to or of the nature of a zone

zonate.explanation: Having zones of a different color or texture, as rings or bands.
botany , marked with zones or concentric bands of color.
zoology , having zones of color or texture; belted, girdled, or ringed; zoned.
Having or appearing to have multiple zones , such as of color or texture.
Having different colors, textures, or other patterns form a pattern of rings, bands, or stripes.

zonation.explanation: Arrangement or formation in zones; zonate structure.
The distribution of organisms in biogeographic zones.
In phytogeography , the distribution of vegetation in œcological zones or belts, or the general concept of such distribution. See zone , 8.
In cytology , a term applied to a differentiation of the cytoplasm of the plant cell into concentric layers.
An arrangement or distribution of things into zones .

zone.explanation: An area or a region distinguished from adjacent parts by a distinctive feature or characteristic.
A section of an area or territory established for a specific purpose, as a section of a city restricted to a particular type of building, enterprise, or activity.
An area of a given radius within which a uniform rate is charged, as for transportation or shipping.

Any of the five regions of the surface of the earth that are loosely divided according to prevailing climate and latitude, including the Torrid Zone, the North and South Temperate Zones, and the North and South Frigid Zones.
A similar division on any other planet.
A portion of a sphere bounded by the intersections of two parallel planes with the sphere.
An area characterized by distinct physical conditions and supporting a particular type of flora and fauna.
A ringlike or cylindrical growth or structure.
A region or stratum distinguished by composition or content.
A zone defense.
A belt or girdle.
To divide or designate into zones.
To surround or encircle.
( in the zone ) In a state of focused attention or energy so that one's performance is enhanced.
A girdle or belt worn as an article of dress.

A belt or band round anything, as a stripe of different color or substance round an object; figuratively, any circumscribing or surrounding line, real or imaginary; a circuitous line, path, or course; an inclosing circle.
Specifically, in geography , one of five arbitrary divisions of the earth's surface, bounded by lines parallel to the equator, each named according to its prevailing temperature; a climatic belt.

Any continuous tract or belt differing in character from adjoining tracts; a definite area or region within which some distinguishing circumstances exist or are established: as, the zones of natural history, distinguished by special forms of vegetable or animal life; a zone of free trade; a free zone on the border of a country or between adjoining states.
In mathematics , a part of the surface of a sphere included between two parallel planes.
In crystallography , a series of planes having their lines of intersection parallel.
A portion of the surface of a sphere cut off by one plane.
A belt on the surface of the earth or of the celestial sphere included between two parallels to the equator.
In phytogeography , a vegetation ring or belt: referring more directly to the plant-content itself or to the areas marked by œcological difference.
One of the different levels of a shaft-furnace, characterized according to the reaction which takes place in it: as, the zone of fusion, reduction- zone , etc.
Transition climate, in which the variation is greater than 15° C. and less than 20° C.
Land climate, in which the variation is greater than 20° C. and less than 40° C.

Extreme continental climate in which the variations are greater than 40° C. Koeppen's climatic zones are arbitrary divisions based upon temperature considerations as follows: A tropical zone having an average temperature of over 68° F.
A subtropical zone which has the same temperature during 4 to 11 months.
A constant temperate zone with a temperature between 50 and 68° F.
A hot summer temperate zone which has an average temperature that sometimes falls below 50° F.
A moderate summer and cold winter temperate zone with a temperature between 50 and 68° F.
A cold zone with a prevailing temperature below 50° F.

A polar zone with an average temperature always below 50° F. Wojeikoff's climatic zones are distinguished according to the quantity and character of the rainfall. Twelve climatic regions are shown upon his maps as follows: A zone of ocean trades with very rare rainfalls.
A region of equatorial rains, including the zone of calms.
A region of rain which prevails throughout the year.
A subtropical zone with rainless summers.
A zone of the fall and winter rains of middle latitudes.
The zone of summer rainfall of middle latitudes.
The zone of equal distribution of rain throughout all seasons.
A polar region with light snows in winter.
Deserts and semi-deserts with an annual precipitation less than 250 mm. (10 in.).
(10) The region of the Australian monsoons.
(11) The region of the Asiatic monsoons.

(12) The region of the African monsoons. Climatic zones in altitude correspond to climatic zones in latitude and are marked by the retardation of the dates of the development of vegetation; this retardation amounts to about ten days for every 300 meters of increase in altitude in the Alps, or four days for 800 meters in France.

zoned.explanation: Having zones, or concentric bands; striped.
Simple past tense and past participle of zone .

zones.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zone .

zonetime.explanation: The standard time throughout a time zone that is the actual time at the meridian on which the time zone is based.
The time in a particular timezone , as opposed to standard time .

zonic.explanation: A girdle; a zone; a belt.

zoning.explanation: Legislative action for the purpose of regulating the use of property and the construction of buildings within the area under the jurisdiction of the legislative body concerned.
dividing an area into zones or sections reserved for different purposes such as residence and business and manufacturing etc

zonite.explanation: Any one of the body rings of a myriapod.

zonites.explanation: In conchology , a genus of pulmonate gastropods, referred to the family Helicidæ , or to the Limacidæ , or to the Vitrinidæ , and giving name to the Zonitinæ.

zonochlorite.explanation: A zeolitic mineral, perhaps related to thomsonite, occurring in massive form in cavities in amygdaloid: it often shows bands of different colors.

zonoid.explanation: A finite vector sum of line segments

zonoplacental.explanation: mammalogy , having a zonary deciduate placenta; of or pertaining to the Zonoplacentalia.

zonoplacentalia.explanation: Those deciduate mammals in which the placenta is zonary, as contrasted with Discoplacentalia ; the Zonaria. The carnivores, the elephant, and the hyrax are examples.

zonotrichia.explanation: A genus of large and handsome American finches, of the family Fringillidæ ; the crown-sparrows.

zonula.explanation: In anatomy and zoology , a small zone, belt, or ring; a zonule.
Any of several small belt -like regions.

zonular.explanation: zoology , specifically, diffuse: applied to a diffuse form of placenta. See zonary .
Of or pertaining to a zone; zone-shaped.
Pertaining to a zonule or zonules.

zonule.explanation: A small zone, as of a ligament.
A little zone, belt, or band; a zonula.
A little zone , or girdle ; a zonula .

zonure.explanation: Any lizard of the genus Zonurus in a broad sense, or of the family Zonuridæ : as, the rough-tailed zonure, Zonurus cordylus.
Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky situations.
Any one of several of South African lizards of the genus Zonura, common in rocky environments.

zonurus.explanation: The typical genus of Zonuridæ : so named from the rings of spiny scales on the tail, as of Z. giganteus.

zoo.explanation: A park or an institution in which living animals are kept and usually exhibited to the public.
A place or situation marked by confusion or disorder.
A park where live animals are exhibited .
Any place that is wild , crowded , or chaotic .

zoobenthos.explanation: benthic organisms that are animals or zoomorphic protists

zoochemistry.explanation: Animal chemistry; the chemistry of the constituents of the animal body.
Animal chemistry; particularly, the description of the chemical compounds entering into the composition of the animal body, in distinction from biochemistry .
Animal chemistry ; particularly, the description of the chemical compounds entering into the composition of the animal body, in distinction from biochemistry .

zoochlorella.explanation: Any of various one-celled green algae that live symbiotically within the cells of aquatic invertebrate organisms such as sponges and sea anemones or within certain protists.

One of the green pigmentary particles, or minute corpuscles of green coloring matter, which are found in various low invertebrates, as the hydras among polyps and the stentors among infusorians. Compare zoöxanthella .
One of the small green granulelike bodies found in the interior of certain stentors, hydras, and other invertebrates.

zoochore.explanation: A plant whose seeds, fruits, or other parts are dispersed by animals.
A plant whose seeds , spores , or fruit are dispersed by animals.

zoocyst.explanation: A cyst, formed by various protozoans and protophytes, whose contents break up into many germinal granules or spores; a kind of sporocyst.
A cyst formed by certain Protozoa and unicellular plants which the contents divide into a large number of granules, each of which becomes a germ.
A variety of encysted rhizopods resembling a sporocyst , except in the thickness and number of the protective layer.

zoocytium.explanation: The common gelatinous matrix or support of certain compound or colonial infusorians, composed of a substance secreted by and containing the individual animalcules; an infusorial syncytium; a zoöthecium. Compare zoödendrium . See cut under Epistylis .
The common support, often branched, of certain species of social Infusoria.

zoodendrium.explanation: The zoöcytium or zoöthecium of certain infusorians, which is much branched or of arborescent form. See cut under Epistylis .
The branched, and often treelike, support of the colonies of certain Infusoria.

zooecium.explanation: The ectocyst, or outer chitinous or calcified cell, in which a polypide of the Polyzoa is lodged, and into which a polypide can be retracted after protrusion; one of the cells of the cœnœcium, containing a polypide.
One of the cells or tubes which inclose the feeling zooids of Bryozoa. See Illust. of sea moss .
One of the cells or tubes which enclose the feeling zooids of Bryozoa .

zooerastia.explanation: The practice of a human engaging in sexual intercourse with an animal
sexual activity between a person and an animal

zooflagellate.explanation: Any of the heterotrophic flagellates of the phylum Zoomastigophora
flagellate protozoan lacking photosynthesis and other plant-like characteristics

zoofulvin.explanation: A yellow carotenoid pigment present in the feathers of some birds

zoogamy.explanation: The coupling, mating, or pairing of animals of opposite sexes for the purpose of reproduction or propagation of their kind; sexual reproduction; gamogenesis.

zoogenic.explanation: Originating in or produced by animals.
geology , noting rocks the constituents of which have been furnished by animals as distinguished from plants, as, for example, shell limestones, guano beds, etc.
Of or pertaining to zoögeny, animal production.
originating , or produced by animals rather then plants

zoogeny.explanation: The fact or the doctrine of the origination of living beings and the formation of their parts or organs. Also zoögony .
The doctrine of the formation of living beings.
The doctrine of the formation of living beings.

zoogeography.explanation: The biological study of the geographic distribution of animals, especially the causes and effects of such distribution.
The scientific study of the geographical distribution of animal species .

zoogloea.explanation: Any of various highly motile, aerobic bacteria of the genus Zoogloea found especially in wastewater, where the cells aggregate into flocculent, gelatinous masses.
A mass of such bacteria or other bacteria.
A colony or mass of bacteria embedded in a viscous gelatinous substance, characteristic of a transitory stage through which rapidly multiplying bacteria pass in the course of their evolution .

zoogloeal.explanation: Of or relating to the zoogloea .

zoogonous.explanation: That gives birth to live offspring (rather than laying eggs)

zoograft.explanation: A surgical graft of tissue from an animal to a human .

zoographer.explanation: One who describes animals, their forms and habits.
one who carries out zoography ; a describer of animals

zoographic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the description of animals.

zoographist.explanation: One who describes or depicts animals; a descriptive zoölogist.

zoography.explanation: The biological description of animals and their habitats.
The description of or a treatise on animals; descriptive zoölogy.
A description of animals, their forms and habits.
A description of animals , their forms, and habits; descriptive zoology .

zooid.explanation: One of the distinct individuals of a colonial invertebrate animal, such as a bryozoan, that arise asexually by budding.

In biology , something like an animal; that which is of the nature of an animal, yet is not an animal in an ordinary sense, and is not the whole of an animal in a strict sense; one of the “persons” or recognizably distinct entities which compose a zoön; that product of any organism, whether of animal, vegetable, or equivocal character, which is capable of spontaneous movements, and hence may have an existence more or less apart from or independent of the parent organism.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an animal.
An organic body or cell having locomotion, as a spermatic cell or spermatozooid.
An animal in one of its inferior stages of development, as one of the intermediate forms in alternate generation.
One of the individual animals in a composite group, as of Anthozoa, Hydroidea, and Bryozoa; -- sometimes restricted to those individuals in which the mouth and digestive organs are not developed.
An organic body or cell having locomotion , as a spermatic cell or spermatozoid .
An animal in one of its inferior or early stages of development , as one of the intermediate forms in alternate generation.
One of the individual animals in a composite group, as of Anthozoa , Hydroidea, and Bryozoa ; — sometimes restricted to those individuals in which the mouth and digestive organs are not developed.
one of the distinct individuals forming a colonial animal such as a bryozoan or hydrozoan

zooidal.explanation: Of or pertaining to a zooid.
Of or pertaining to a zooid .

zookers.explanation: An expression of mild annoyance , surprise etc.

zoological.explanation: Of or relating to animals or animal life.
Of or relating to the science of zoology.

zoologically.explanation: In a zoölogical manner; according to the principles of zoölogy.

zoologist.explanation: One who is versed in zoölogy; a biologist.
One who is well versed in zoölogy.
a specialist in the branch of biology dealing with animals

zoologize.explanation: To study zoölogy; esp., to collect animals for study.

zoology.explanation: The branch of biology that deals with animals and animal life, including the study of the structure, physiology, development, and classification of animals.
The animal life of a particular area or period.
The characteristics of a particular animal group or category.
A book or scholarly work on zoology.
that part of biology which relates to the animal kingdom, including the structure, embryology , evolution , classification , habits, and distribution of all animals, both living and extinct .

zoom.explanation: To make a continuous low-pitched buzzing or humming sound.
To move while making such a sound.
To move rapidly.
To increase suddenly and dramatically.
To act or proceed swiftly and energetically.
To simulate movement rapidly away from or toward a subject using a zoom lens or other optical device.
To cause text or other graphics in a window or frame to appear larger on the screen.
To cause to zoom.
The act or sound of zooming.
A zoom lens.
a humming noise from something moving very fast
a quick ascent
a big increase
an augmentation of a view as with a lens
to move fast with a humming noise
to fly an airplane straight up
to move rapidly
to go up sharply
to change the focal length of a zoom lens
to manipulate a display so as to magnify or shrink it
rise rapidly
the act of rising upward into the air
move with a low humming noise
move along very quickly
a rapid rise

zoomania.explanation: An excessive or abnormal love of animals

zoomastigina.explanation: in some classifications considered a phylum of the kingdom Protista; holozoic or saprozoic flagellates

zoomed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of zoom .

zoomelanin.explanation: A black pigment derived from the feathers of some birds.
A pigment giving the black color to the feathers of many birds.
A pigment giving the black color to the feathers of many birds.

zoometry.explanation: Measurement and comparison of the sizes and proportions of animals or animal parts.

zooming.explanation: A sound or motion that zooms .

zoomorphic.explanation: Having the shape , form , or likeness of an animal .

zoomorphism.explanation: Attribution of animal characteristics or qualities to a god.
Use of animal forms in symbolism, literature, or graphic representation.
The representation of gods as animals or the attributing of animal characteristics to gods.
The use of animal figures in art and design or of animal symbols in literature.
The viewing of human behavior in terms of the behavior of animals.
the attribution of animal forms or qualities to a god

zooms.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of zoom .

zoon.explanation: An individual animal produced from an egg.

zoonal.explanation: Of or pertaining to a zoon .

zoonic.explanation: Of or pertaining to animals; obtained from animal substances.
Of or pertaining to animals ; obtained from animal substances.

zoonomy.explanation: The laws of animal life collectively considered; the science which treats of the causes and relations of the phenomena of living animals; the vital economy of animals; animal physiology.
The laws of animal life, or the science which treats of the phenomena of animal life, their causes and relations.
The laws of animal life, or the science which treats of the phenomena of animal life, their causes and relations.

zoonosis.explanation: A disease of animals, such as rabies or psittacosis, that can be transmitted to humans.
An animal disease , such as rabies or anthrax , that can be transmitted to humans.
an animal disease that can be transmitted to humans

zoonotic.explanation: of or relating to or constituting zoonosis

zooparasite.explanation: Any organism that is parasitic to an animal

zooparasitic.explanation: Being or pertaining to a zooparasite .

zoopathology.explanation: The study of disease in animals; veterinary pathology.

zoophaga.explanation: [ lowercase ] Flesh-eating or carnivorous animals collectively considered: a term of no exact classificatory meaning.
The carnivorous and insectivorous marsupials, as collectively distinguished from the herbivorous marsupials, or Botanophaga. The opossum is an example.
A division of gastropods including carnivorous forms.
An artificial group comprising various carnivorous and insectivorous animals.

zoophagan.explanation: A carnivorous animal; a sarcophagan; especially, a member of the Zoöphaga , 2.
A animal that feeds on animal food.

zoophile.explanation: A person sexually attracted to animals .

zoophilia.explanation: A paraphilia in which sexual gratification is derived from fantasies or acts involving animals.
The tendency to feed or grow on animal tissue.
An affinity or fondness for animals .
A paraphilia involving sexual attraction to animals.

zoophilism.explanation: A preference of a parasite or vector to feed on non-human animals
Zoophilia , a sexual inclination towards bestiality

zoophilist.explanation: A lover of animals - Robert Southey

zoophily.explanation: A love of animals; a sympathy or tender care for living creatures which prevents all unnecessary acts of cruelty or destruction.

zoophoric.explanation: Bearing or supporting the figure of an animal.
Bearing or supporting the figure of an animal .

zoophorous.explanation: The part between the architrave and cornice; the frieze; -- so called from the figures of animals carved upon it.
The part between the architrave and cornice ; the frieze ; — so called from the figures of animals carved upon it.

zoophytal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the zoophytes .

zoophyte.explanation: An invertebrate animal, such as a sea anemone or a sponge, that superficially resembles a plant. Not in scientific use.
A member of the Zoöphyta , in any sense; a radiate; a phytozoan.

The term is a loose popular equivalent of the technical designation; but it is convenient, and may be employed for any of the Zoöphyta in a proper sense, as corals, seaanemones, acalephs, and sponges. The chief objection to its use is its continued application to those polyzoans which are of coralline aspect, as these have no affinity with cœlenterates.

Any one of numerous species of invertebrate animals which more or less resemble plants in appearance, or mode of growth, as the corals, gorgonians, sea anemones, hydroids, bryozoans, sponges, etc., especially any of those that form compound colonies having a branched or treelike form, as many corals and hydroids.
Any of various invertebrate animals which resemble plants , such as sponges , corals and sea anemones .
any of various invertebrate animals resembling a plant such as a sea anemone or coral or sponge

zoophytic.explanation: of, or relating to the zoophytes

zoophytical.explanation: Of or pertaining to the zoophytes .

zoophytoid.explanation: Pertaining to, or resembling, a zoöphyte.

zoophytology.explanation: The science or natural history of zoophytes.

zooplankton.explanation: Plankton that consists of animals, including copepods, rotifers, jellyfish, and the larvae of sessile animals such as coral and sea anemones.
Free-floating small protozoa , crustaceans (such as krill ), etc. and the eggs and larvae from larger animals.
animal constituent of plankton; mainly small crustaceans and fish larvae

zooplasty.explanation: Surgical transfer of tissue from an animal to a human.
the surgical grafting of tissue from an animal to a human ; zoografting

zoopraxiscope.explanation: An instrument developed by Eadweard Muybridge in the 1870's, similar to the phenakistoscope . The instrument involves a disc that includes serial pictures being rotated in front of a light source, projecting them upon a screen , to exhibit the natural movements of animals and the like.

zoopsia.explanation: Visual hallucinations of animals. These can occur in any condition causing hallucinations but are most typical of delirium tremens .
visual hallucination of animals; sometimes occurring in delirium tremens

zoopsychology.explanation: The study of psychology in animals.

zoosperm.explanation: One of the spermatic particles; spermatozoid.
One of the spermatic particles; spermatozoid , spermatozoon .

zoospermia.explanation: The presence of live spermatozoa in the semen

zoosporangium.explanation: A sporangium in which zoospores develop.
Any multicellular organ among the algæ or fungi giving rise to zoöspores.
In botany , a sporangium or spore-case in which zoöspores or zoögametes are produced. See sporangium , and cuts under Puccinia and spermogonium.
A spore, or conceptacle containing zoöspores.
A sporangium , or conceptacle containing or producing zoospores .

zoospore.explanation: A motile flagellated asexually produced spore, as of certain algae, oomycetes, and fungi.
In botany , a spore capable of moving about; a motile spore, or swarmspore.
An animal spore; one of the minute flagelliform bodies which issue from the sporocyst of sporiparous animalcules; a swarm-spore.

A spore provided with one or more slender cilia, by the vibration of which it swims in the water. Zoöspores are produced by many green, and by some olive-brown, algæ. In certain species they are divided into the larger macrozoöspores and the smaller microzoöspores. Called also sporozoid , and swarmspore .
A motile asexual spore of some algae and fungi .
an asexual spore of some algae and fungi that moves by means of flagella

zoosterol.explanation: A sterol, such as cholesterol, that is produced by animals rather than plants.
Any sterol found in animal tissue

zootechnician.explanation: One working in the field of zootechnics , or animal husbandry .

zootechny.explanation: The domestication, breeding, and improvement of animals; the technology of animal husbandry.
The science and technology of animal husbandry

zootherapy.explanation: The use of living animals for medical treatment or as an adjunct to medical diagnosis .

zootic.explanation: Containing the remains of organized bodies; -- said of rock or soil.
Containing the remains of organized bodies; -- said of rock or soil.

zootomical.explanation: Pertaining to zootomy , the dissection of animals.

zootomist.explanation: One who dissects the bodies of animals; one who is versed in zoötomy; a comparative anatomist.
One who dissects animals, or is skilled in zoötomy.

zootomy.explanation: The dissection or anatomy of animals .

zootoxin.explanation: A toxin produced by an animal
a toxin resembling bacterial toxins in its antigenic properties that is found in the fluids of certain animals

zootrophic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the nourishment of animals.
Of or pertaining to the nourishment of animals.

zootype.explanation: A proposed archetype of the form of all animals , based not on a shared body plan but on conserved molecular homologies.
An animal totem ; an animal (or animal figure) that is taken as symbolic of a deeper abstraction.

zooxanthella.explanation: Any of various yellow-brown photosynthetic dinoflagellates that live symbiotically within the cells of other organisms, especially certain corals and other marine invertebrates.
An animal of the genus Symbiodinium, a yellow dinoflagellate , notably found in coral reefs .

zopilote.explanation: One of the smaller American vultures or Cathartidæ , as the turkey-buzzard or carrion-crow; a gallinazo; a urubu. See aura , and cuts under Cathartes and urubu.
The urubu, or American black vulture.

zorgite.explanation: A metallic mineral consisting of the selenides of lead and copper, found at Zorge, in the Harz mountains.

zori.explanation: A flat sandal with thongs, usually made of straw or leather.
Japanese sandals made from rice straw or lacquered wood, worn with a kimono for formal occasions.
a sandal attached to the foot by a thong over the toes

zoril.explanation: An African animal of the genus Zorilla.
Some Central or South American skunk; one of the Mephitinæ , as the conepate; a zorrino. See cut under Conepatus .

zorilla.explanation: A carnivorous mustelid mammal (Ictonyx striatus) of Africa, resembling a skunk in appearance and in its method of defense.
A genus of African skunk-like quadrupeds, representing the subfamily Zorillinæ.
Either one of two species of small African carnivores of the genus Ictonyx allied to the weasels and skunks.

zorille.explanation: A small, carnivorous , nocturnal African mammal resembling a skunk

zoster.explanation: A belt or girdle worn by men in ancient Greece.
In ancient Greek costume , a belt or girdle; originally, a warriors' belt round the loins, afterward any girdle or zone, but chiefly one of a kind worn by men.
Same as herpes zoster (which see, under herpes ).
An ancient Greek waist - belt for men.
The disease called herpes zoster (from the typically beltlike pattern of its rash); shingles .
eruptions along a nerve path often accompanied by severe neuralgia

zostera.explanation: A genus of aquatic plants, of the order Naiadaceæ , type of the tribe Zostereæ.
A genus of plants of the Naiadaceæ , or Pondweed family. Zostera marina is commonly known as sea wrack , and eelgrass .
(or in some classifications family Zosteraceae) small genus of widely distributed marine plants

zosteraceae.explanation: used in some classifications: essentially equivalent to Potamogetonaceae

zosterops.explanation: A very extensive genus of Meliphagidæ (also referred to the Dicæidæ ), giving name to the subfamily Zosteropinæ , characterized among related genera by the absence or spurious character of the first primary, and named from the conspicuous orbital ring of most of its members.
[ lowercase ] Any bird of this genus.
A genus of birds that comprises the white-eyes. See white-eye .

zounds.explanation: Used to express anger, surprise, or indignation.
An exclamation formerly used as an oath, and an expression of anger or wonder.

zowie.explanation: An indication of astonishment or admiration .

zoysia.explanation: Any of several creeping grasses of the genus Zoysia, native to Southeast Asia and Australasia and widely cultivated for lawns.
any of a genus (Zoysia) of creeping perennial grasses of southern Asia and New Zealand having fine wiry leaves and including some suitable for lawn grasses, especially in warm regions
any of several creeping grasses of the genus Zoysia

zs.explanation: Symbol for the zeptosecond , an SI unit of time equal to 10−21 seconds .

zucchetto.explanation: A skullcap worn by certain Roman Catholic clerics, varying in color according to rank.
small skullcap worn by Roman Catholic clergy

zucchini.explanation: A variety of summer squash (Cucurbita pepo) having an elongated shape and a smooth, thin, dark green rind.
A particular variety of Cucurbita pepo, a squash / marrow .
This fruit, considered as a food ; or, a dish made from it.
small cucumber-shaped vegetable marrow; typically dark green
marrow squash plant whose fruit are eaten when small

zuchetto.explanation: A skullcap covering the tonsure, worn under the berretta. The pope's is white; a cardinal's red; a bishop's purple; a priest's black.
: A skullcap worn by Roman Catholic clergymen . The Pope's is white; a cardinal's red; a bishop's purple; a priest's black.

zufolo.explanation: A little flute or flageolet, especially such as is used in teaching birds.
A little flute or flageolet, especially that which is used to teach birds.
A little flute or flageolet , especially that which is used to teach birds .

zugzwang.explanation: A situation in a chess game in which a player is forced to make an undesirable or disadvantageous move.
A situation in which a player is forced to make a move .

zumbooruk.explanation: A small cannon mounted on a swivel, usually shorter and with larger bore than the zingal.
A small cannon supported by a swiveled rest on the back of a camel, whence it is fired, -- used in the East.
A small cannon supported by a swiveled rest, especially as mounted on the back of a camel.

zunyite.explanation: A fluosilicate of aluminium, occurring in glassy transparent tetrahedral crystals of the hardness of quartz: found at the Zuñi mine in Colorado.
A fluosilicate of alumina occurring in tetrahedral crystals at the Zuñi mine in Colorado.
A fluorosilicate mineral of alumina occurring in tetrahedral crystals, chemical formula Al13Si5O20(OH,F)18Cl.

zurlite.explanation: An impure form of humboldtilite (melilite) which occurs in opaque squares or octagonal prismatic crystals in calcareous blocks in Monte Somma.

zwanziger.explanation: A silver coin of Austria of the nineteenth century, equivalent to 20 kreutzers, and worth 8⅜ pence English (about 17 cents).
An Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers, or about 10 cents.
An Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers , or about 10 cents.

zwieback.explanation: A usually sweetened bread first baked as a loaf and later cut into slices and toasted.
Slices of bread made from a rich dough, which have been heated in an oven until they are thoroughly dried and are of a deep yellow color.
A kind of biscuit or rusk first baked in a loaf and afterwards cut and toasted.
a usually sweetened bread enriched with eggs that is baked and then sliced and toasted until dry and crisp
a teething food for toddler children
slice of sweet raised bread baked again until it is brown and hard and crisp

zwieselite.explanation: A variety of triplite found near Zwiesel in Bavaria.
A brown to black mineral containing manganese , iron , phosphorus , oxygen , and fluorine .

zwinglianism.explanation: The doctrines of Ulrich Zwingli (1484–1531) and his followers. See Zwinglian .

zwitter.explanation: In petrography , a variety of greisen, associated with tin ores, of somewhat variable composition, chiefly quartz, mica, topaz, with more or less tin ore.

zwitterion.explanation: A molecule, especially an amino acid, containing a positively charged ion at one end and a negatively charged ion at the other.
A molecule , such as an amino acid , that carries both a positive and a negative charge .

zwitterionic.explanation: Of a pertaining to a zwitterion

zydeco.explanation: Popular music of southern Louisiana that combines French dance melodies, elements of Caribbean music, and the blues, played by small groups featuring the guitar, the accordion, and a washboard.
A form of folk music originating among the Creole people of south-west Louisiana, using accordions and washboards heavily.
music of southern Louisiana that combines French dance melodies with Caribbean music and blues

zygadenus.explanation: A genus of liliaceous plants, of the tribe Veratreæ.

zygadite.explanation: A variety of albite, occurring in thin tabular twin crystals: it is found at Andreasberg in the Harz.

zygaenid.explanation: Any member of the moth genus Zygaenidae .

zygal.explanation: shaped like a yoke , or like the letter H

zygantrum.explanation: In herpetology , the fossa upon the posterior face of the neural arch of a vertebra of serpents and some lizards, for the reception of the zygosphene of a succeeding vertebra, the series of vertebræ being more effectively interlocked thereby than is accomplished by the zygapophyses alone. Compare cut under zygosphene .

zygapophyseal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the zygapophysis

zygapophysis.explanation: One of two usually paired processes of the neural arch of a vertebra that articulates with corresponding parts of adjacent vertebrae.

A process upon the neural arch of a vertebra corresponding to that called oblique or articular in human anatomy, provided with a facet for articulation with the same process of a preceding or succeeding vertebra, thus serving to interlock the series of vertebral arches.
One of the articular processes of a vertebra, of which there are usually four, two anterior and two posterior. See under vertebra .
One of the articular processes of a vertebra , of which there are usually four, two superior and two inferior .

zygenid.explanation: Any one of numerous species of moths of the family Zygænidæ , most of which are bright colored. The wood nymph and the vine forester are examples. Also used adjectively.
Of or pertaining to moths in the family Zygaenidae .
Any one of numerous species of moths of the family Zygaenidae , most of which are bright colored.

zygion.explanation: In craniometry , the points at which the greatest bizygomatic diameter is found.

zygite.explanation: In Greek antiquity , an oarsman of the second or middle tier in a trireme. Compare thranite and thalamite.

zygnema.explanation: A genus of fresh-water algæ, typical of the order Zygnemaceæ , having cells with two axile many-rayed chlorophyl-bodies near the central cell-nucleus, each containing a starch-granule, and the zygospore undivided, mostly contracted, and developed in the middle space between two united pairing-cells or in one or the other of the conjugating-cells.
type genus of the family Zygnemataceae

zygnemaceous.explanation: Zygnemaceæ or to the genus Zygnema.

zygnemataceae.explanation: pond scums: common freshwater algae forming green slimy masses

zygobranchia.explanation: A division of marine gastropods in which the gills are developed on both sides of the body and the renal organs are also paired. The abalone (Haliotis) and the keyhole limpet (Fissurella) are examples.

zygobranchiata.explanation: An order or suborder of Gastropoda , having paired gill-combs, or right and left ctenidia, symmetrically disposed in the pallial chamber on each side of the neck, a pair of osphradia or olfactory tracts, paired nephridia of unequal size, and distinct sexes.

zygobranchiate.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Zygobranchia.
Of or pertaining to the Zygobranchia

zygocactus.explanation: small genus of Brazilian cacti having flat fleshy usually branched joints and showy red or pink flowers followed by red fleshy fruits

zygodactyl.explanation: Having two toes projecting forward and two projecting backward, as certain climbing birds.
A zygodactyl bird, such as a parrot.
ornithology , yoke-toed: noting those birds, or the feet of those birds, which have the toes disposed in pairs, two before and two behind.
A yoke-toed bird; a bird having the toes arranged in pairs.
Having two toes pointing forward, and two pointing backward; zygodactylous .
Any such bird (such as the parrot .)
(of bird feet) having the first and fourth toes directed backward the second and third forward

zygodactylae.explanation: The zygodactylous birds. In a restricted sense, applied to a division of birds which includes the barbets , toucans , honey guides , and other related birds.

zygodactyle.explanation: A group of arboricole non-passerine birds whose toes are yoked in pairs, two before and two behind: synonymous with Scansores (which see).
The zygodactylous birds. In a restricted sense applied to a division of birds which includes the barbets, toucans, honey guides, and other related birds.

zygodactylic.explanation: Yoke-footed; having the toes disposed in pairs; -- applied to birds which have two toes before and two behind, as the parrot, cuckoo, woodpecker, etc.
yoke-footed ; having the toes disposed in pairs. Applied to birds which have two toes before and two behind, as the parrot , cuckoo , woodpecker , etc.

zygodactylism.explanation: The yoking of the toes of a bird's foot in anterior and posterior pairs; the zygodactyl character or condition of a bird or its toes.

zygodactylous.explanation: Having two toes pointing forward, and two toes pointing backward.

zygoid.explanation: relating to a zygote or to zygosis

zygolabialis.explanation: The lesser zygomatic muscle; the zygomaticus minor.

zygoma.explanation: The bony arch or arcade of the cheek, formed by the malar or jugal bone and its connections: socalled because it serves to connect bones of the face with those of the skull about the ear.
The malar or jugal bone itself, without its connections.
The cavity under the zygomatic process of the temporal bone; the zygomatic fossa.
The jugal, malar, or cheek bone.
The zygomatic process of the temporal bone.
the slender arch formed by the temporal process of the cheekbone that bridges to the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

zygomatic.explanation: zoology and anatomy , of or pertaining to the malar or jugal bone, or this bone and its connections; constituting or entering into the formation of the zygoma; jugal.
zygomaticofacial , or malar , running between the orbital aud anterior surfaces;
zygomaticotemporal , or temporal , running between the orbital and temporal surfaces.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the zygoma.

the arch of bone beneath the orbit, formed in most mammals by the union of the malar, or jugal, with the zygomatic process of the temporal bone. In the lower vertebrates other bones may help to form it, and there may be two arches on each side of the skull, as in some reptiles.
a process of the temporal or squamosal bone helping to form the zygomatic arch.
of or relating to the cheek region of the face
the arch of bone beneath the eye that forms the prominence of the cheek

zygomaticofacial.explanation: anatomy , of or pertaining to the zygoma and the face: specifying
Relating to the zygomatic bone and face .

zygomaticofrontal.explanation: Relating to the zygomatic bone and frontal bone .

zygomaticosphenoid.explanation: Relating to the zygomatic bone and sphenoid bone .

zygomaticotemporal.explanation: anatomy , of or pertaining to the zygoma and the temporal bone or fossa: specifying
Relating to the zygomatic bone and temples .

zygomaticum.explanation: The suborbital ring, a chain of small ossicles following the lower margin of the orbital cavity in fishes.

zygomaticus.explanation: One of several small subcutaneous muscles arising from or in relation with the zygoma, or malar bone.
One of several small subcutaneous facial muscles arising from or in relation with the zygoma .

zygomaxillare.explanation: In craniometry , the lower terminus of the zygomaxillary suture.

zygomorphic.explanation: Having bilateral symmetry, as the flowers of a pea plant.
Symmetrical bilaterally; -- said of organisms, or parts of organisms, capable of division into two symmetrical halves only in a single plane.
capable of division into symmetrical halves by only one longitudinal plane passing through the axis

zygomorphous.explanation: capable of division into symmetrical halves by only one longitudinal plane passing through the axis

zygomycete.explanation: Any of numerous fungi of the division Zygomycota, characterized by a sexual phase of the life cycle during which specialized hyphae fuse to form a zygospore, and including various food molds.
In botany , a fungus belonging to the group Zygomycetes.
An organism of the phylum Zygomycota .

zygomycetes.explanation: A group of fungi characterized by the production of zygospores. It embraces the Mucorini, Entomophthoreæ, Chytridiaceæ, Ustilagineæ , etc.
class of fungi coextensive with subdivision Zygomycota

zygomycetous.explanation: botany , of or pertaining to the Zygomycetes.

zygon.explanation: A connecting rod or bar; a yoke in general.
In anatomy , an H-shaped fissure of the brain, as the paroccipital fissure.
In the cerebrum , the short crossbar or stem that connects the two pairs of branches of a zygal fissure .

zygophyllaceae.explanation: small trees, shrubs, and herbs of warm arid and saline regions; often resinous; some poisonous: genera Zygophyllum, Tribulus, Guaiacum, Larrea

zygophyllum.explanation: A genus of plants, type of the order Zygophylleæ.
usually tropical herbs or shrubs having ill-smelling foliage and flower buds that are used as capers: bean capers

zygophyte.explanation: A plant characterized by the production of zygospores; a plant in which reproduction consists in a confluence of two similar protoplasmic masses. See cut under conjugation , 4.
Any plant of a proposed class or grand division (Zygophytes, Zygophyta, or Zygosporeæ), in which reproduction consists in the union of two similar cells. Cf. oöphyte .
Any plant of a proposed class or grand division in which reproduction consists in the union of two similar cells.

zygoptera.explanation: Odonata which includes the two families Calepterygidæ and Agrionidæ. They have the wings of the two pairs equal in size, or the hind ones a little the smaller.

zygopteran.explanation: Any of various insects of the order Zygoptera ; damselfly .

zygose.explanation: botany , pertaining to or characteristic of zygosis or conjugation.
Relating to a zygote or to zygosis .

zygosis.explanation: The union of gametes to form a zygote; conjugation.
Asexual intercourse of protoplasmic bodies, resulting in their confluence and coalescence; the process and result of conjugation in protozoans or other of the lowest organisms. See conjugation , 4.
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Förster, 1869).] A genus of hymenopterous insects.
In botany , conjugation; the fusion or union of two distinct cells or protoplasmic masses for reproduction. See conjugation , 4.
The process of the merging of two gametes. Same as conjugation .
The union of gametes to form a zygote ; conjugation .

zygosity.explanation: The genetic condition of a zygote, especially with respect to its being a homozygote or a heterozygote.
The quality or characteristics of a zygote

zygosperm.explanation: A spore formed by the union of the contents of two similar cells, either of the same or of distinct individual plants. Zygosperms are found in certain orders of algæ and fungi.
A spore formed by the union of the contents of two similar cells , either of the same or of distinct individual plants. Zygosperms are found in certain orders of algæ and fungi .

zygosphene.explanation: In herpetology , the wedge-shaped process from the fore part of the neural arch of the vertebræ of serpents and some lizards, which fits into a corresponding fossa, the zygantrum, on the posterior part of the neural arch of a preceding vertebra, and serves thus to interlock the series of arches more effectually than would be done by zygapophyse's alone. Compare cut under zygantrum
A median process on the front part of the neural arch of the vertebræ of most snakes and some lizards, which fits into a fossa, called the zygantrum , on the back part of the arch in front.
A median process on the front part of the neural arch of the vertebrae of most snakes and some lizards , which fits into a fossa called the zygantrum on the back part of the arch in front.

zygosphere.explanation: A plant's gamete which can form a zygospore by uniting with a similar one.

zygosporangium.explanation: In botany , a sporangium in which zygospores are produced.
A sporangium which produces a single zygospore .

zygospore.explanation: A thick-walled diploid or multinucleate spore formed by the union of similar gametes in certain fungi and algae.

In botany , a spore formed in the process of reproduction in some algæ and fungi by the union or conjugation of two similar gametes or protoplasmic masses: called isospore by Rostafinski. Also zygosperm, zygote. See spore , conjugation , 4 (with cut).
A spore formed by the union of several zoöspores; -- called also zygozoöspore .
A spore formed by the union of several zoospores .
a plant spore formed by two similar sexual cells

zygosporophore.explanation: In botany , a club-shaped or conical section of a hypha adjoining a gamete-cell after its delimitation.

zygote.explanation: The cell formed by the union of two gametes, especially a fertilized ovum before cleavage.
The organism that develops from a zygote.
In biology , a fertilized ovum, or the equivalent, in plants and in unicellular organisms, of a fertilized egg; the product of the conjugation of gametes, or sexual cells.
(genetics) the diploid cell resulting from the union of a haploid spermatozoon and ovum (including the organism that develops from that cell)

zygotene.explanation: The stage in prophase of meiosis during which homologous chromosomes become paired.
The intimate pairing of homologous chromosomes during the synaptic stage of meiosis
the second stage of the prophase of meiosis

zygotic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a zygote .
of or relating to a zygote

zygotically.explanation: By means of, or in terms of, zygosis .

zymase.explanation: The enzyme complex in yeasts that catalyzes the breakdown of sugar into alcohol and carbon dioxide.
A soluble ferment, or enzyme. See enzyme .
Any of a group of enzymes that catalyzes the fermentation of simple carbohydrates to ethanol and carbon dioxide .
a complex of enzymes that cause glycolysis; originally found in yeast but also present in higher organisms

zyme.explanation: The living germ or other poison, of whatever nature, which is believed to be the specific cause of a zymotic disease.
The morbific principle of a zymotic disease.
The morbific principle of a zymotic disease.

zymic.explanation: Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation; -- formerly, by confusion, used to designate lactic acid.
Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation

zymin.explanation: An enzym, in a general sense.
A ferment ( enzyme ), especially one used medicinally

zymite.explanation: In the Greek Church, the priest who celebrates the Eucharist with unleavened bread.

zymogen.explanation: A substance from which an enzym may be formed by internal change. Also zymogene .
A mother substance, or antecedent, of an enzyme or chemical ferment; -- applied to such substances as, not being themselves actual ferments, may by internal changes give rise to a ferment.
A proenzyme , or enzyme precursor , which requires a biochemical change (i.e. hydrolysis) to become an active form of the enzyme.
any of a group of compounds that are inactive precursors of enzymes and require some change (such as the hydrolysis of a fragment that masks an active enzyme) to become active

zymogene.explanation: One of a physiological group of globular bacteria which produces fermentations of diverse nature; -- distinguished from pathogene .
One of a physiological group of globular bacteria which produces fermentations of diverse nature; — distinguished from pathogene .

zymogenic.explanation: Of or relating to a zymogen.
Pertaining to, or formed by, a zymogene.
Capable of producing a definite zymogen or ferment.

a microörganism, such as the yeast plant of the Bacterium lactis , which sets up certain fermentative processes by which definite chemical products are formed; -- distinguished from a pathogenic organism . Cf. Micrococcus .
pertaining to, or formed by, a zymogene
capable of producing a definite zymogen or ferment

zymogram.explanation: A strip or band of electrophoretic medium showing the pattern of enzymes or isoenzymes after their separation by electrophoresis.
A strip of electrophoretic material on which enzymes are visibly separated through histochemical methods (eg by zone electrophoresis).

zymoid.explanation: Resembling a zymin or ferment ( enzyme )

zymologic.explanation: Of or pertaining to zymology ; zymological .

zymological.explanation: Of or pertaining to zymology ; zymologic .

zymologist.explanation: One who is skilled in zymology. Also zumologist .
One who is skilled in zymology, or in the fermentation of liquors.
One who is skilled in zymology , or in the fermentation of liquors.

zymology.explanation: The science of or knowledge concerning fermentation.
A treatise on the fermentation of liquors, or the doctrine of fermentation.
A treatise on the fermentation of liquors, or the doctrine of fermentation.
The science of or knowledge concerning fermentation .
the branch of chemistry concerned with fermentation (as in making wine or brewing or distilling)

zymolysis.explanation: Digestion by means of the non-organized ferments.
The action of enzymes, such as digestion or fermentation; also, the changes produced by such action.
The action of enzymes in breaking down organic substances during fermentation
a process in which an agent causes an organic substance to break down into simpler substances; especially, the anaerobic breakdown of sugar into alcohol

zymolytic.explanation: of or relating to or causing fermentation

zymome.explanation: An old name for the gluten of wheat that is insoluble in alcohol. Also zimome .
A glutinous substance, insoluble in alcohol, resembling legumin; -- now called vegetable fibrin , vegetable albumin , or gluten casein .
A glutinous substance, insoluble in alcohol , resembling legumin ; now called vegetable fibrin, vegetable albumin, or gluten casein.

zymometer.explanation: An instrument for ascertaining the degree of fermentation of a fermenting liquor. Also zymosimeter .
An instrument for ascertaining the degree of fermentation occasioned by the mixture of different liquids, and the degree of heat which they acquire in fermentation.
An instrument for ascertaining the degree of fermentation occasioned by the mixture of different liquids, and the degree of heat which they acquire in fermentation; a zymosimeter .

zymophyte.explanation: A bacterioid ferment that liberates fatty acids from neutral fats.
A fermentation produced by bacteria , yeasts or similar micro-organisms .

zymoplastic.explanation: That converts a substance (such as a proenzyme ) into an enzyme

zymosan.explanation: An insoluble carbohydrate from the cell wall of yeast, used especially in the immunoassay of properdin.
an insoluble carbohydrate , obtained from the cell walls of yeast , used in the bioassay of blood serum

zymoscope.explanation: An instrument used to determine fermentation efficiency by measurement of carbon dioxide produced.
An instrument, contrived by Zenneck, for testing the fermenting power of yeast, by bringing it in contact with sugar-water and observing the quantity of carbonic anhydrid evolved.
An apparatus for determining the fermenting power of yeast by measuring the amount of carbonic acid evolved from a given quantity of sugar.

zymosimeter.explanation: An instrument for ascertaining the degree of fermentation occasioned by the mixture of different liquids, and the degree of heat which they acquire in fermentation; a zymometer .

zymosis.explanation: An infectious disease, especially one caused by a fungus.
Fermentation of any kind. Also zymolysis .
A fermentation; hence, an analogous process by which an infectious disease is believed to be developed.
A fermentation; hence, an analogous process by which an infectious disease is believed to be developed.
(medicine) the development and spread of an infectious disease (especially one caused by a fungus)
a process in which an agent causes an organic substance to break down into simpler substances; especially, the anaerobic breakdown of sugar into alcohol

zymosthenic.explanation: Tending to strengthen the activity of an enzyme .

zymotechnics.explanation: The art of managing fermentation. Compare zymurgy .

zymotic.explanation: Same as zymotic disease . See I.
Of, pertaining to, or caused by, fermentation.
Designating, or pertaining to, a certain class of diseases. See Zymotic disease, below.
any epidemic, endemic, contagious, or sporadic affection which is produced by some morbific principle or organism acting on the system like a ferment.
Relating to or caused by infection .
relating to or caused by infection
of or relating to or causing fermentation

zymotoxic.explanation: immunity . Sometimes used synonymously with toxophoric

zymurgy.explanation: The branch of chemistry that deals with fermentation processes, as in brewing.

That department of technological chemistry which treats of the scientific principles of wine-making, brewing, and distilling, and the preparation of yeast and vinegar, in which processes fermentation plays the principal part.
The chemistry of fermentation with yeasts , especially the science involved in beer and wine making.
the branch of chemistry concerned with fermentation (as in making wine or brewing or distilling)

zyrian.explanation: A member of a Finnic people living in northeastern Russia, principally in the government of Vologda. Also Ziryanian, Siryanian.
the Finnic language spoken by the Komi
